Keywords: Earth-abundant transition metal and metal oxide Nanomaterial Electrochemical sensor Energy conversion Fuel cells Water splitting Energy storage Lithium ion battery
A B S T R A C T
Earth-abundant transition metal and metal oxide (EATM&MO) nanomaterials offer numerous positive attributes such as catalytic activity, selective enzyme-mimicking catalysis, energy harvesting and storage, green chemistry and atom economy guided by size and morphology induced intrinsic properties at the nanoscale. Noble metal nanomaterials have long been played a central role and highly efficient for various electrochemical applications but their high cost and least abundance unfortunately make them less attractive towards industrial applications. In this perspective, the design and development of EATM&MO nanomaterials with unique features are imperative in the fabrication of potential electrochemical devices. This review gives an account of the various emerging synthesis of EATM&MO nanomaterials and their nanocomposites using numerous chemical strategies for the state-of-the-art electrochemical applications. A variety of synthetic strategies for the production of diverse size-, morphology-, and composition- controlled EATM&MO nanomaterials has been described for emerging applications such as sensing and biosensing, fuel cells, photovoltaics, water electrolyzer, photo-electrochemical water electrolyzer, and energy storage systems (Lithium Ion Batteries, LIBs). Recent progress, important approaches, structure property relations, and future outlook towards the EATM&MO nanomaterials fabrication for diverse electrochemical devices are highlighted.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In nanotechnology, design of nanomaterials becomes highly critical for both fundamental academic research and potential industrial applications, including sensors and biosensors, catalysis, energy conversion and storage systems, etc. A variety of nanostructured materials with one-, two-, and three-dimensions have shown exceptional properties and experienced explosive progress over the past decade [1–3]. For instance, in the area of catalysis science and technology, nanoscale catalysts have been considered as semi-heterogeneous due to the advantage of unique catalytic activity both under heterogeneous conditions in terms of high catalytic activity and selectivity, simple separation of catalyst and reusability, and other unique properties in comparison to bulk scale catalysts [4–7]. Nanomaterials provide high specific surface area, enormous binding sites, high porosity, large surface energy, and rich surface textural features which play a significant role on the adsorption and chemical reaction at the surface as well as interface in sensor and electrochemical energy conversion and storage based technologies. The extremely small size of nanomaterials also favors the transportation kinetics and thermodynamics of heterogeneous reactions happening at the interface in terms of favorable mass,

Electrochemical technology is a vast and diverse area of science, and is very difficult to define accurately the limitation or boundary of electrochemistry due to their impact in interdisciplinary science involving chemistry, physics, and biology. It has also been recognized for contributions in the field of medicine and environments, which highlights the importance of chemical science in the current technological era [11–16]. Electrochemical sensor and biosensor platforms have profound impacts on everyday life. The major concerns toward the development of sensor devices include the demand for low cost and provision for on-line monitoring, particularly for environmental, food safety, biological, biomedical and point-of-care applications [17–20]. The electrochemical technologies based on novel nanomaterials are the most gifted strategy because of their simplicity, high sensitivity as well as specificity and simultaneous measurements. Owing to the steady growth of energy consumption in many sectors, intermittent environment of non-renewable energy resources and urgency to contain emission of CO2 related global warming, the energy field confronts many challenges in the 21st century. To mitigate the above issues, alternative environment friendly renewable energy technologies are being extensively explored. In this perspective, development of electrochemical technology using nanomaterials for energy conversion, energy storage and proper energy distribution system is very much essential.
Earth-abundant transition metals (Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Mn, etc.) and their oxides based nanomaterials display exceptional characteristics, including (i) mimicking the metal surface activation and catalysis [21–23], (ii) as support materials for a variety of noble metal nanoparticles (Au, Ag, Pt, Pd, and their bi-, and tri-metallic nanomaterials) [24–26], (iii) reducing the operation cost of industrial processes due to their high Earth abundances [27–30], (iv) amenable for biocompatibility after appropriate functionalization or conjugation of nanomaterials due to their more labile environment in comparison to their second- and third-row counterparts and complex mechanistic manifolds [8,31,32], (v) appealing attractive catalytic properties alternative to precious nanomaterials for numerous energy conversion reactions [33–35], (vi) exhibiting superior energy storage capabilities [36–39], and (vii) sustainable in a long run with their low cost, availability, comparatively less toxicity, wider chemistry and chemical reactivity [40–43]. Owing to the aforementioned reasons, nanostructured materials based on Earth-abundant transition metals and metal oxides (EATM&MO) are considered as the potential candidates in the present context which prompt us to comprehensively review the diverse synthesis protocols, effect of size and morphology, the state-of-the-art electrochemical applications, including sensors and biosensors, electrochemical energy conversion and energy storage. This review theme supports well with the current research trend in the field and development of high performance electrochemical technologies. The demand for the design of highly active and stable EATM&MO nanomaterials based catalysts will certainly increase with persistent efforts aimed at transforming the laboratory technologies to the marketplace.
The present review is mainly comprised of four sections. Section 1 provides a general introduction dealing with the advantages, challenges, and recent progress in nanostructured EATM&MO materials, including Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Mn, etc. for sensing, energy conversion and energy storage applications. Section 2 describes a variety of strategies and techniques for the synthesis of EATM&MO nanomaterials based on mono-, bi-, and tri-metals and/or metal oxide of pure, alloy and core-shell nanomaterials, all-encompassing the impacts of different parameters with respect to structure and size over their performance. Section 3 covers the state-of-the-art electrochemical applications of the EATM&MO nanomaterials that may have served as exceptional catalysts, supports, and better charge storage properties for several electrochemical reactions towards sensors, fuel cells, and Li-ion batteries (LIBs). Section 4 addresses the critical aspects and challenges linked with the identification of potential new Earth-abundant transition metal and metal oxide nanomaterials in the electrochemical technologies.

sections.heading: 2.1. Structure and dimension dependant properties
sections.text:
Earth-abundant transition metals and metal oxides can be synthesized by numerous preparative strategies, which may display different structural characteristics including new physical, electronic, chemical, and surface properties. The choice of synthetic methods for the production of size and structure controlled EATM&MO is a crucial aspect. The realization of specific dimension, composition, crystal structure, defects level, vacancies, electronic states, and other surface properties of EATM&MO nanomaterials remains unclear. It is a key challenge to understand the relationship between the structural characteristics and properties/functionalities. The attractive characteristics of EATM&MO nanomaterials afford them structural flexibility for extensive electrochemical applications. Novel characteristics including physical, chemical, electronic, optical and magnetic properties of EATM&MO nanomaterials can easily be tuned by simply altering chemical synthesis. This section briefly summarize the relation between the structure, dimension and properties with respect to EATM&MO nanomaterials design processing.
There are numerous efforts already made on preparation of unique advanced structures for size dependant activities of EATM& MO nanomaterials. In general, the particle size reduction leads to more specific accessible surface areas, while their specific morphology influence the stacking of facets and overall crystal structures. In terms quantum mechanics, the confinement of electron in zero-, one- and two-dimensions of EATM&MO nanomaterials enables fine tuning of electronic properties which dictate their applications in various electronic, optoelectronic, and electrochemical systems. A variety of metal oxides based thin films through wellordered features was produced to demonstrate the photoelectrochemical performance in solar energy applications [44]. Fig. 1 illustrates the direct correlation between thin film nanostructure and catalytic activity of TiO2 and NiO for hydrogen production. The higher photocurrents produced in the water splitting with columnar films (Fig. 1) were attributed to a larger surface area causing enormous generation of electron-hole pairs in comparison to the dense structures [44]. In addition, the mean average distance that a
hole was travelling to reach the surface was also smaller in the columnar-morphology, causing in lower charge carrier recombination. The amount of photocurrents produced varies with film thickness and therefore, by controlling growth parameters desired thin film structures in regard to catalytic activity could be achieved. Even though, thicker metal oxide films are desirable to harvest more photons, converting these photons to photocurrent with 100% efficiency is virtually impossible due to rapid electron-hole recombination when the metal oxide film dimension is greater than the critical film thickness, which often varies based on the chemical composition.
Shao co-workers [45] have recently prepared layered oxides Li1.2Mn0.56Co0.12Ni0.12O2 with several nanostructures and morphologies, such as microspheres, microrods, nanoplates, and irregular nanoparticles. The developed nanomaterials display strong morphology-dependent electrochemical properties towards lithium ion batteries (LIBs). As shown in Fig. 2, the electrochemical investigation clearly exemplified that the performance of the different layered nanostructures follows the order: microrods > microspheres > nanoplates > irregular particles. Due to the synergistic effect of porous texture and one-dimensional architectures with facile conducting pathway, the microrods exhibited a remarkable electrochemical performance compared to other morphological structures. Mechanistically, a relatively large contact area between the electrolyte and electrode, more open channels for lithium ion diffusion within the electrode materials, and numerous Li active sites arising from porous structure are some of factors responsible for high performance of microrods. Additionally, the one-dimensional architecture also facilitate the electronic conductivity by molecular wiring and thereby improve the overall electrochemical performance. Moreover, the robust secondary microstructure formed from the nanostructured primary particles could overcome the electrode pulverization, loss of electrical contact, minimize parasitic side reactions upon cycling, leading to high cycling stability. These structure-dependent features mostly influence the specific capacity and Li transportation kinetics of the electrode materials.
Meanwhile, a few atom thick structure directing agents with in-plane covalent bonds could produce unique nanostructures which can not only enhance electrochemical performance but also flexibility of a particular device. As like graphene, two-dimensional transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs) have shown unique physical and chemical properties due to the ascription of anisotropic effects of the materials as well as the quantum confinement effects as it is thinned a few-layer sheet. It has been reported that these possessions amplify anisotropy and can create a host of enhancements in the electronic, optical, structural, thermal and mechanical properties [46]. For example, the semimetallic-to-semiconducting conversion measured in ultrathin TiS2 [47], the metallic-to-insulating transition of TaS2 [48], and special effects on the band-gaps indirect-to-direct transition [49], widen of the bandgap over ∼50%. It was observed that Mo and W based TMDCs, a single layer have involved remarkable improvements in electrocatalytic activity [46].
Additionally, increase in surface area to volume ratio vis-à-vis surface free energy at nanoscale dimension would promote electrocatalytic activities and also enhance other surface related electrochemical process including supercapacitors. For instance, Maduraiveeran et al. [16] developed an in-situ process for the synthesis of cobalt quantum dots (Co QDs) with a dimension of ∼3.2 nm regularly distributed on reduced graphene oxide (rGO). This nanocomposite showed an outstanding electrocatalytic property towards the water oxidation with a high mass activity (1250 A g−1) and a small Tafel slope (∼37mV dec−1) with a low overpotential (η) (0.37 V) in alkaline electrolyte, which was associating positively with RuO2, IrO2 and Pt/C catalysts. Because of small dimension, high dispersion, and the synergy between abundant catalytically active Co QDs sites and improved electron transfer produced from the graphene ensured in superior electrocatalytic properties. Advantageously, the solution processing of high quality freestanding thin films through simple techniques including vacuum filtration, spin coating, drop casting, spray-coating, and inkjet printing plays major role in numerous practical applications such as sensor, fuel cells, supercapacitors, and solar cells. Due to the facile film forming capability of the EATM&MO with other materials to form composites or hybrids, they offer favorable effects as the active layers in functional systems such as sensor, energy conversion and energy storage devices. In addition, the scope of electrocatalytic activities of EATM&MO can be subtly altered through the defect- and vacancy-engineering. More importantly, instant accessibility of surface atoms also permits to tune the surface-related electrocataltyic activities in terms of surface modification/
functionalization with chemical and biological molecules, element doping, and engineering of defect sites. The interfaces and superlattices of mixed transition metal oxide display properties such as superconductivity, magneto-electric coupling, and the quantum Hall effect that are not present in either of the constituent materials. Such interfaces are also known to enclose the creation of defects either during growth or spontaneously at thermal equilibrium. These defects may considerably alter the physio-chemical possessions of the materials. For example, Mishra et al. investigated the combined experimental and computational studies with (LaFeO3)2/(SrFeO3) superlattices [50]. The two constituent materials lack any polar displacements in their bulk
form, whereas in the case of superlattice, the Fe atoms experience polar displacements. The introduction of oxygen vacancies prompts the Fe polar displacements, which was demonstrated by employing DFT calculations. The ordered oxygen vacancies are certainly exists predominantly in the LaFeO3 regions and the formation of oxygen vacancies are likely at distinct sites.
The ability to produce nanostructured EATM&MO materials with preferred morphology, dimension, composition, layer thickness, unique texture, specific crystal planes, cationic/anionic defects, and surface property gains much significance towards advanced study of their physical, chemical, electronic, and optical properties, as well as the investigation of numerous potential electrochemical applications. In addition, the convincing properties and encouraging applications of EATM&MO nanostructures can endorse the swift development of numerous reliable synthetic approaches for preparing EATM&MO nanomaterials. In the following section, we center on the outline of different well-developed synthetic strategies to fabricate EATM&MO nanomaterials that have been extensively employed or proven to be applicable in a diverse material synthesis. The advances and limitations of each process are described beside with addition of experimental evidences.

sections.heading: 2.2. Chemical vapor deposition method
sections.text:
Chemical vapor deposition (CVD) method is considered as a gas-phase synthetic process that typically performed under elevated temperatures either in a vacuum chamber or under inter atmosphere. Precursor vaporization, nucleation, and the growth of crystals are the three main events for the formation mechanism on the nanoparticles in the vapor phase [51–53]. The CVD approach is very simple, inexpensive, and also operates continuously with high product yield for desired nanoparticles preparation. Generally, most of the synthetic methods for preparation of nanoparticles in the gas phase are mainly based on homogeneous nucleation in the gas phase and subsequent condensation followed by coagulation. Biswas co-workers [54] developed a new aerosol-chemical vapor deposition (ACVD) process for the production of various morphologies of titanium dioxide (TiO2) such as dense, columnar, granular, and branched tree-type structures and columnar nickel oxide (NiO). The controlled nanostructures of metal oxides were employed as the counter electrode in a photoelectrochemical cell in its place of platinum (Pt). The photoelectrochemical performance of the developed oxide electrode was tested towards the water splitting with various thickness and morphology of film. In this ACVD method, as the boundary layer was skinny, the temperature incline was not actual great, and the thermophoretic velocity was trivial in comparison to the diffusion velocity (conventional CVD) that grades in deposition. As shown in Fig. 3, a controlled design was apparent contingent upon the treating circumstances subsequently the diffusional deposition [54]. A well-controlled structure and dimension of nanomaterials were attained subject on the numerous distinctive times, including residence time (τres), reaction time (τrxn), sintering time (τsin), collision time (τcol), three different deposition systems namely vapor dominant, vapor-particle mixed, and particle dominant were acquired (Fig. 4). The reaction time (τrxn) for the vapor precursor to be transformed to the oxide was estimated based on the subsequent equation: τrxn= [C]i/Ri. where [C]i represents the concentration of the metal oxide and Ri means the reaction rate [55].
Fan et al. prepared nanocrystalline Earth-abundant transition metal carbide M3C (M: Fe, Co, Ni) embedded in graphitic shells sustained with steeply allied graphene nanoribbons (VA-GNRs) via a hot filament chemical vapor deposition (HF-CVD) approach [56]. Fig. 4a shows the preparation process of M3C-GNRs (M: Fe, Co, Ni). Initially, VA-GNRs arrays were prepared on the Si-wafer with atomic hydrogen treatment which is promising for depositing metal nanoparticles, as the metal particles may easily go through
and stay on the tips or side walls of the VA-GNRs as displayed in Fig. 4b. Carbonization of metal carbide nanoparticles with HF-CVD method was conducted at 675 °C after the deposition of metal M (M: Fe, Co, Ni) onto the VA-GNRs arrays. The fabricated nanocomposite is composed of a great amount of ultrafine M3C NCs, and these NCs with irregular shapes were less prone to aggregation. Meanwhile, the production of phase-pure Fe3C, Co3C, and Ni3C are predominantly challenging at high temperature and reducing environments distinguishing of various carbide syntheses repeatedly consequence in the development of metallic iron, cobalt, nickel or mixed M/M3C (M: Fe, Co, Ni) products [57]. Other alternative synthesis approaches have also been established to make phase pure M3C (M: Fe, Co, Ni) products, including spray-pyrolysis, sonolysis, or arc-discharge method for numerous electrochemical applications.
Nanoporous Fe3N/Fe4N (FexN) film on a 3D electrically conductive interconnected graphene network was prepared for high performance oxygen evolution reactions by Yu et al. [58]. Ni foam was coated with high electrically conductive graphene networks and then the samples were decorated with the Fe(NO3)3 precursor dispersed in dimethylformamide (DMF) solvent, which was slowly dried in a sealed sample box. The resulting samples were annealed under an Ar atmosphere at 400 °C for 30min and thermally converted to nitride by passing NH3/Ar gas at 400 °C for 1 h. As shown in the SEM images of Fig. 5a–c, the iron nitride film was uniformly formed on the graphene/Ni foam surface after thermal nitridation. The formed iron nitride film was in the form of nanoporous structures, rather than a uniform dense film due to low volatility of DMF solvent at room temperature, resulting in uniform distribution of the Fe(NO3)3 precursor on graphene and gradual decomposition with an increase in the annealing temperature. On the other hand, the control experiments of changing the solvent from DMF to ethanol solution, the as-prepared iron nitride catalyst was aggregated on the graphene surface without any nanoporous structure because of the low boiling point and high volatile nature of the ethanol. The present method is very simple when compared to other procedures for making porous nanomaterials including electrochemical anodization, template synthesis, etc. High-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) (Fig. 5d) image clearly shows lattice fringes with spacing distances of 0.19, 0.21, and 0.24 nm corresponding to (0 0 2) lattice plane of Fe4N28 and (1 1 1) and (1 2 0) lattice planes of Fe3N crystals, respectively.
One-, two- and three-dimensional EATM&MO nanomaterials have been received much interest in the expansion of numerous electrochemical devices because of their diverse properties in comparison to their bulk counterparts. Mudusu et al. fabricated onedimensional SnS nanostructures on gold catalyst modified on sapphire and Si substrates using a CVD approach at various temperatures changing from 500 to 950 °C [59]. The possible growth mechanism of SnS nanowires may be a vapor–liquid–solid (VLS) approach (Fig. 6). Thus, the formed SnS nanowires were single crystalline, and possess preferential growth direction ((1 0 0) planes), suggesting that the progress of high quality 1D SnS nanowires permit to grow many SnS based devices such as batteries, solar cells,
etc. The generation of transition metal dichalcogenides using a CVD method is usually through the volatilisation and thermolysis of precursors contain the requisite elements. In gaseous phase, produced reactive metal and chalcogen ions can then react to structure the TMDC monomer. For instance, Yang et al. developed MoSe2 and CVD-grown MoS2 heterojunctions which were stacked on SiO2/Si substrate to form 2D heterostructures with type-II band alignment [60]. The stacked multi-heterostructured layered materials could extend the application scope of 2D materials systems to create new opportunities in future high performance nano- and optoelectronic devices. The fabricated heterojunctions based transistors display significant photovoltaic properties, which may be modulated by back gate. Warner co-workers recently investigated the atomic structure of slight tributary realms that nucleate on monolayer MoS2 which was grownup using CVD [51]. As shown in Fig. 7, the trifling secondary bilayer areas include a faceted
geometry with three-fold regularity and embrace two different alignments with 60° rotation relation to an underlying single crystal sheet of monolayer MoS2. The two discrete directions were connected with the 2H and 3R mounding configuration. Atomic resolution images were verified by annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (ADF-STEM) that display the edge termination, lattice direction, and stacking order of the bilayer domains which was comparative to the fundamental MoS2 monolayer. The CVD approach is one of the crucial strategy to grow or form the various structures and dimensions of several types of transition metal/ oxide nanomaterials and is widely used for the materials-processing technology. This method offers the less waste generation and high pure materials, particularly in cold-wall reactors due to the attribution of heated surfaces only will be coated. The majority of the elements present in the periodic table may be easily placed on any material using CVD strategy. The design and development of interesting characteristics of mono-, bi- and tri- metallic or oxides of transition metal based nanomaterials by deposition on various substrates using CVD approach enable multi-level electrochemical devices.

sections.heading: 2.3. Hydrothermal method
sections.text:
Hydrothermal method provides many significant advantages over other conventional and non-conventional synthetic methods for the production of EATM&MO nanomaterials, which can make a wide variety of functional nanomaterials for numerous electrochemical applications [61–65]. It embraces a facile and template approach for the production of transition metal and metal oxide nanomaterials. The dimension, morphological variation, and crystalline characteristics can be tuned by varying the temperature, pressure, and precursor concentration and composition. Fu et al. [45] prepared various structures and dimensions including microspheres, microrods, nanoplates, and irregular nanoparticles of Li1.2Mn0.56Co0.12Ni0.12O2 lithium-rich layered oxide (LLO) materials using hydrothermal or co-precipitation method for LIBs. The characteristics of the electrode materials rest highly on crystallite size, shape, composition, and architecture which would be an influential way to optimize the performance of various electrochemical applications. Due to the complex chemical compositions and the requirement of prolonged calcination at high temperature, controlling the shape, composition, and structure of Li-rich layered oxides is very challenging for application in LIBs. In addition, the integration of different components with distinct physical and chemical properties with Li-rich layered cathode materials of common morphologies is also a potential pathway to improve the battery performance. Fig. 8 shows the schematic illustration of the formation processes of various nanostructured LLO materials for LIBs. The morphology and dimension of the nanomaterials is highly dependent on the precursor composition, solvent, and synthesis conditions as presented in Fig. 9. The precursor morphology and the final nanomaterials of LLO were initially characterized by SEM (Fig. 9). Fig. 9a–c display SEM images of the spherical precursor and LLO product, respectively prepared by solvothermal method using isopropanol as a solvent. The Ni-Co-Mn carbonate precursors appeared as microspheres with a suave surface with an average diameter of ∼1 μm. The precursor microspheres were then transformed into hierarchical LLO microspheres after mixing with LiOH·H2O and annealing at high temperature. Fig. 9e and f,g present SEM images of the rod-shaped precursor and products, respectively obtained by using of ethanol/water mixture as solvent. The developed Li-Ni-CoMn-C2O4 precursor consist of uniform microrods with 100–200 nm diameter and 2–3 μm length as depicted in Fig. 9e. The porous hierarchical LLO microrods were formed from the smooth microrods precursors after high temperature calcination which involves a large agglomeration of nanoplates with a size of 100–200 nm (Fig. 9f,g). The length and diameter LLO microrods were ∼2–3 μm and ∼400–500 nm, respectively. Fig. 9i–k show SEM images of the sheet-like precursor and plate-like LLO product, respectively and it suggest that the thicknesses of the as made Ni-Co-Mn hydroxide nanosheet precursors was ∼10 nm (Fig. 9i). The nanosheet-like morphology was transformed into nanoplates with increased thickness ∼30 nm by mixing with lithium salts and calcined at high temperature. The smooth LLO nanoplates transform to a hexagonal shape and calculated average edge length of ∼150 nm. (Fig. 9j and k). Fig. 9m–o present the SEM images of the cube-like precursor and irregular-shaped LLO, respectively; whereas as prepared LiNi-Co-Mn-C2O4 precursor has a cubic shape (sizes of 1–2 μm (Fig. 9m)). The above results suggest that a variety of morphologies including 3D-microspheres, 1D-porous microrods, 2D-nanoplates, and irregular particles have been successfully prepared by simply using of different solvents and synthetic strategies. Owing to numerous merits such as easy process, rapid preparation, less expensive,
and bulk scale production, hydrothermal method has widely been employed for the production of TMDs and their nanocomposite with graphene, including transition metal, M (Mo, W, or V), such as metal salts and chalcogenide, X (S, Se, or Te), such as thiourea, Lcysteine, and thioacetamide. The application of hydrothermal method can able to produce 2D- and 3D- architectures of TMDs based composites with various microstructures, including flower-, sheet-, rose-, leaf-, and sphere-like [66].
Owing to the interesting and unique properties, hollow spherical nanostructures are considered as a class of nanomaterials, which have evoked diverse interest in various electrochemical applications. The production of narrow size distribution and well-defined morphology of hollow nanomaterials based on Earth-abundant transition metal and metal oxide nanomaterials with innovative template-free methods increase their importance for providing more accessible active sites towards various electrochemical reactions. Due to the inappropriateness among the substrate and the materials, former surface adaptation or functionalization of hard-template is needed for preparation of nanomaterials with desired chemical composition. Therefore, soft-template directed strategies have used widely for the synthesis of hollow spherical materials. Additives-directed hydrothermal strategy provides a precise structure of shape and dimension controlled EATM&MO nanomaterials. Among numerous organic templates, natural products and polymers are promising as plentiful and flexible tools for structuring of oxide nanomaterials. Primarily, the metal ions are formed complex on natural or polymer template surface and pyrolitic deletion of templates generates a lot of hollow oxide spheres (CuO, MgO, Fe2O3, NiO, Co3O4 and CeO2). For instance, Sasidharan et al. synthesized a variety of hollow spherical metal oxide nanomaterials including NiO [67], WO3 [68], TiO2 [69], etc. [70] using micelles as soft-template and successfully applied for electrochemical energy storage applications. For instance, ∼28 nm size of NiO hollow spheres nanomaterials was prepared using a soft-template self-assembly procedure where ABC triblock copolymeric micelles of poly(styrene-b-acrylic acid-b-ethylene oxide) (PS–PAA–PEO) with core–shell–corona structural design provides as colloidal-template for synthesis of NiO hollow nanospheres as presented in Fig. 10(top) [67]. The inorganic ions such as alkali cations (Li+, Na+ and K+) are considered as a pattern for the preparation of shape-controlled morphology of EATM&MO nanomaterials. These templates are directed to interact with both assured facets of the rising nanocrystal and the discriminatory incorporation of additive ions, which favors the construction of various EATM&MO nanomaterials. As shown in Fig. 10(bottom), single crystalline α-Fe2O3 nanotubes have formed in the presence of sodium sulfate and sodium phosphate through the synergistic communication of two dissimilar inorganic additives [71]. The presence of phosphate ions induces the anisotropic expansion beside the c direction via favored adsorption along the specific crystal planes. In addition, the presence of a huge amount of complexing ions would guide to the suspension of the insecure tips of the mounting spindle-like morphologies. The relationship of disbanding and selectivity of adsorption enables the configuration of tubular α-Fe2O3 nanostructures.
Recently, Zhang et al. [72] reported Co3O4 quantum dots with a crystallite size of ∼2 nm, produced via a simple hydrothermal method. This method utilizes controlling the concentration of oxygen vacancies and increase the population of mixed oxidation states of Co2+ over Co3+ for the efficient catalytic oxygen and hydrogen production in alkaline solution. The inexpensive copious transition
metal and their oxides such as Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, etc. have been extensively used as a potential alternative to the commercial Pt/C catalysts. In order to improve the electroactive sites of transition metal and metal oxide nanomaterials, the integration of graphene with transition metal nanomaterials to form nanocomposites under hydrothermal conditions is a successful approach to progress catalytic activities by promoting the charge transfer in electrodes. For instance, Liu et al. [73] developed Co-CoO/N-rGO and Ni-NiO/ N-rGO by a pyrolysis of graphene oxide (GO)-support Co and Ni salts, respectively. The mixed metal oxides based on spinel structures display improved electrochemical concert than their nanoparticle counterparts due to hierarchical architectures with high surface area, superior permeability united with superior porosity. Sun co-workers [74] prepared hierarchical ZnxCo3−xO4 nanoarrays via codepositing of mixed-metal (Zn and Co) nitrites. Various amounts of Zn(NO3)2 and Co(NO3)2 were mixed to the expansion solution as precursor to adjust the concentrations of Zn-doping and the nanostructural features were significantly changed when Zn was doped in the crystal lattice. Pure Co3O4 sample showed extended rod with sharp tip which were compactly full-grown on the Ti foil (Fig. 11A). The average diameter and length were calculated as ∼400.0 nm and ∼10.0 μm, respectively. The surface morphological features
noticeably altered after the doping of Zn2+ into Co3O4. The rhombus-like ZnxCo3−xO4 pillar (length of 15 μm) arrays were observed at high cobalt concentration (Co(NO3)2/Zn(NO3)2 = 4) (Fig. 11B). With the ratio of 3 (Co/Zn) in the precursor solution, small nanoneedles (length: ∼2 μm) were developed on the side and end of the pillar (Fig. 11C). Fig. 11D displays the SEM image which demonstrated that the pillars have a clear-cut rhombic contour and the average edge length was calculated to be ∼2 μm when the ratio of Zn to Co was 1:2. The hydrothermal method is a convenient potential approach for the synthesis of numerous transition metal nanomaterials with various compositions and morphologies via the manipulation of precursors, pH, and synthesis temperature. Interesting nano- and micro-structures include nanoparticles, cube, pellet, flower, platelet, sheet, needle, dendrites, and porous network and core-shell materials, all of which may be prepared or supported on various substrate materials. The novel synthesis of nanomaterials of transition metal origin with unique properties creates this strategy as a viable option to obtain nanoscale materials for applications in catalysis and as a support for numerous electrochemical devices.

sections.heading: 2.4. Electrochemical method
sections.text:
Electrochemical deposition of EATM&MO nanomaterials is a simple, rapid, one-pot and cost effective approach which usually involves the assembly of two- or three-electrode cell system. The deposition of transition metal and metal oxide nanomaterials can be directly obtained on an electrode surface by controlling the potential or current of an electrochemical cell. A variety of transition metal and metal oxide nanomaterials may be fabricated by using the electrochemical techniques including cyclic voltammetry (CV), chronoamperometry (CA), chronopotentiometry (CP), chronocoulometry (CC) and pulsed electrodeposition at a fixed or varied potential. Recenly, Huan et al. [75] prepared three-step synthesis of Cu supported porous dendritic Cu/Cu2O/CuO material and further nanostructured with a thin layer of electrodeposited CuO nanoparticles as shown in Fig. 12. The porous structured material obtained from the combination of Cu dendritic growth and the concomitant generation of a foam with macropores because of the intense hydrogen bubbling (Fig. 12a and b), permits a fast diffusion of analyte or active species to the micropores thereby avoiding mass-transfer limitations. The dentric nanostructured CuO material was developed following a simple electrochemical deposition method using Cu complexes bearing N-containing ligands as precursors. The nanomaterials were electrodeposited by applying two CV cycles in the range of −0.5 to 1.0 V to a Cu(imidazole)4Cl2 (0.2 mm) solution in acetonitrile (3% water v/v). As shown in SEM image of resulting material, the electrochemical treatment had not altered the macroporosity but the dendritic structure of the
material caused a significant modification of the surface (Fig. 13a). TEM observation of the sample (Fig. 13b) further revealed the formation of a thin layer of small nanoparticles (< 10.0 nm) on top of the dendrites. Thus formed dense CuO layer at the surface of the dendritic supports effectively inhibits the corrosion of the basal Cu substrate which allowed for good and stable conductivity of the material. The electrodeposition is an interesting approach for making numerous electrodes which may be generated using simple inorganic salts and thermal treatments, allowing an easy and cost effective preparation using Earth abundant metal and oxide.
It is clearly understood that the metal/metal oxide core–shell nanostructure may resolve the poor conductivity and activity of the metal oxide. Over the few years, much pains have been aimed on three-dimensional porous architectures owing to their high specific surface area that can maximize the accessibility of catalytic sites and provide fast diffusion of active species. Xu et al. [76] prepared 3D hybrid foams containing of Cu2O–Cu dendrites with high surface area. These hybrid foams containing Cu2O–Cu dendrites were prepared using an electrochemical deposition method in a solution of 0.75M H2SO4+0.1M CuSO4 (Fig. 14). In this approach, there was energetic hydrogen gas evolution occurred at the electrode surface which played a vital role as soft-template for the creation of foam architecture comprising of dendrites. The average size of Cu foams suited well with an increase in the electrodeposition time, and the pore sizes because of the coalescence of hydrogen bubbles (Fig. 14). In this method, a large current density or high overpotential is required to create the gas-liquid-solid multiple interfaces. Thereby, many bubbles can be generated and adsorbed on the electrode surface to alter the current distribution during electrodeposition. The nucleation, growth, coalescence and separation behaviors of bubbles significantly determine the pore size and distribution of deposited materials. As a result, the pore size of d can be calculated using break-off diameter of the corresponding bubbles:
(1)
in which θ is contact angle, g is gravity acceleration, γ is surface tension, ɨ (A·m−2) is current density, ρ1 and ρg are the liquid and gas densities, respectively. The advantage of this kind of core-shell and 3D porous structures in the design of 3D metal/metal oxide hybrid foams with core–shell structures would be chiefly gorgeous for numerous catalytic applications due to the multiple favorable structures and compositions to accomplish exceptional properties of electrocatalysts. In particular, Cu-based oxides may experience a multiple parallel reactions because of wide range of accessible oxidation states of Cu such as Cu0, Cu+, Cu2+, and Cu3+). SEM images of Cu2O-Cu hybrid foams deposited for 120 s with various magnifications (Fig. 15a–c). The identical porous structure (∼20–60 μm) was clearly seen in the SEM image and the thickness was calculated to be ∼200 μm. The walls of the hybrid consist of large amounts of dendrites and the size of dendrite was ∼5 μm. The abundant pores and dendrites may substantially increase the specific surface area and provide fast transportation for active species. XRD pattern of the Cu2O–Cu foams (Fig. 15d) showed the diffraction peaks observed at 43°, 50°, and 74° correspond to (1 1 1), (2 0 0), and (2 2 0) planes of Cu (JCPDS No. 65-9026), respectively and the peaks at 36° and 42° establish the existence of Cu2O (JCPDS No. 65-3288).
Recently, Maduraiveeran et al. [77] fabricated a variety of transition nanomaterials including mono metal (Fe, Ni and Co) and
bimetallic alloy (CoNi, and CoFe) nanoparticles on a titanium (Ti) substrate via one-step electrochemical deposition by appling the Eapp of −1.0 for 10min in an oxygen-free 5mM metal salt +0.1M Na2SO4 electrolyte solution. The fabricated nanomaterials of Fe, Ni, Co, CoNi, and CoFe NPs were characterized by FE-SEM (Fig. 16a–e). This approach successfully led to different morphologies and dimensions of nanomaterials by one-step electrodeposition method. The FESEM image of the formed nanoparticles on a Ti substrate was found to be particle, cube, pellet-structured nanomaterials were formed. The bimetallic CoFe nanostructures showed numerous shapes including rods, triangles, cubes, and spheres as presented in Fig. 16e. The EDX spectra of the Ti/Fe, Ti/Ni, Ti/Co, Ti/CoNi, and Ti/CoFe electrodes revealed that their compositions with the atomic ratios of Co:Ni and Co:Fe were found to be 40.6:59.4 (1.0:1.4) and 44.9:55.1 (1.0:1.2) for the bimetallic CoNi and CoFe nanoparticles, respectively. The present electrochemical deposition technique comprises a green approach that can make mono-dispersed nanomaterials with huge active surface areas onto the surface of various electrode substrates. Sung co-workers [78] prepared anodized Fe foams (Fe2O3-nanoflakes) with multidimensional architectures of nano/micro-scale as photoelectrode for photoelectrochemical water splitting using electrochemical anodic oxidation. The electrochemical anodic oxidation of freeze-cast Fe foam employed which was applied 80.0 V for 5min at 25 °C in an ethylene glycol electrolyte contain 0.25 wt% NH4F and 2 vol% H2O with the help of ultrasonication. It is understood that the creation of anodic
oxides on metal substrate is based on the equilibrium between the oxide formation of metal through applying electric potential and chemical dissolution of oxides with the electrolyte. In general, the process of etching of metal oxides encompasses the following steps: (i) The formation of M-OH2+ with the protonation of metal oxide ligand, replacement of -OH2+ by -Fx, a nucleophilic substitution which may remove the M-Fx unit from the lattice of metal oxide; (ii) For the M-Fx formation step, the presence of HF, HF2, and H2F2 is needed. Due to these reason, the composition of electrolyte plays a major role that affects the ultimate structure and morphologies of anodic oxide films. The structure, dimension, and thickness of active electrocatalysts may be restricted by manipulating the contest among similar and vertical growth with respect to the substrate. For example, the thickness of deposited layers increases with current density, but reduces as inhibition increases. When the inhibition increases at the constant current density, the lateral enlargement is facilitated to obtain dense and coherent deposits. Consequently, the electrodeposited transition metal and oxides can be well tailored by the modulation between mass transfer characteristics (J/CMez+ or J/Jd) and inhibition intensity, in which J is the current density, CMez+ is the bulk concentration of metal ions, and Jd is the diffusion limiting current density as displayed in Fig. 17 [79]. Experimentally, many material scientists have been examining the superior performance of electrocatalysts by altering preparation methods, annealing conditions, dispersion techniques, precursors and solvents, and current or charge to achieve highly active surface areas and stable catalytic responses. The electrochemical deposition method has several advantages including high purity, better morphological and dimensional control via the use of soft templates, small particle size distribution, increased control over particles distribution, etc. The application of electrochemical deposition methods is vast for the production of variety of nanoscale metals and oxides with interesting geometries by one-pot and facile synthesis environment which may be effortlessly regulated. It is considered as green, fast, simple, and less cost process for the production of transition metal and oxide nanomaterials which is an ideal method for the industrial production and large-scale making of nanomaterials for a varied range of applications.

sections.heading: 2.5. Chemical reduction method
sections.text:
A variety of shape and dimensions-controlled EATM&MO nanomaterials have been synthesized using chemical reducing agents and/or stabilizing agents. Over last two decades, momentous efforts have been made on the design and development of nanomaterials with unique structure and properties that display better surface stabilized reactive sites in comparison to classical materials. Nanosized particles typically have high accessible surface area to make contact with analytes ensuing in superior catalytic activity and other performance in the direction of various applications. The modification of individual nanomaterials via tuning their composition in order to further improve the electrochemical activity at the nanoscale is also an active area of research. The introduction of defects in the host metal and metal oxide structures is also critical for beneficial properties useful for numerous applications. This strategy has long been employed in bulk materials in order to alter the electronic, magnetic, and physical structure of semiconductors [80]. Similarly, the introduction of defects in nanocrystals by dopant incorporation induces numerous stimulating electrochemical properties that are useful for many electrocatalytic reactions and energy storage applications.
The preparation of doped transition metal to metal oxide nanocrystals with controlled nanocrystal size, composition, and internal structure has a great opportunity for further technological advancement. For instance, Jansons et al. prepared numerous first-row transition-metal dopants (Mn, Fe, Co, Cu, and Zn) into In2O3 lattice with dopant concentrations of up to 20 atom% using chemical reduction method. The dopants were incorporated into the oxide lattice without surface segregation. The dopant cations were homogeneously dispersed on the nanocrystal without surface segregation and core localization. The resultant doped In2O3 (a wide bandgap oxide) permits ligand field transitions in visible region of electromagnetic spectrum and which may allow to probe the optical and electrical properties. The electronic transitions of first-row transition-metal dopants with the In2O3 structure show that dopants are situated in octahedral geometries. Thus, the choice of synthetic approach widely influences the growth of oxide nanocrystals, and also precisely controls the morphological structure and composition. The bulk production of mono-, bi-metal or metaloxide alloys and core-shell nanocomposites with numerous carbon nanomaterials including graphene, carbon nanotubes, fullerene, etc. comprising non-precious metals/metal oxides could enable in the advance of functional materials for sensor, electrocatalysis, and other energy applications [16,77,81–87]. As the electrocatalytic activity depends on electrical conductivity of the nanoparticles, the use of carbon and other conductive additives significantly improve the conductivity of the final nanocomposite resulting in overall improved device performance.
A detailed survey of the literature reports suggested that the synthesis of transition metal and metal oxide resulted in larger particle size larger than 10 nm by hydrothermal strategy, which normally requires a complicated process under hydrothermal conditions. The chemical reduction strategy is an effective method for the growth of highly dispersed transition metal and metal oxides nanoparticles which may substantially improve the electrochemical performance. The establishments of the Co QDs/rGO nanocomposites were seen through the reduction of Co2+ and GO by color change beginning light-yellow toward dark-black. The rGO and the Co QD/rGO nanocomposite were characterized by TEM (Fig. 18A) and the HRTEM image of Fig. 18B shows average size of∼3.2 nm for the synthesized Co QDs, homogeneously dispersed in the graphene nanosheets [16]. Selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern was obtained for the Co QDs (Fig. 18C); the concentric circles with diffractions (1 1 1), (2 0 0), (2 2 0) and (3 1 1) planes, respectively ascribed to the face-centred cubic structure of Co quantum dots. The elemental mapping of the Co QD/rGO nanocomposite, suggested uniform Co delivery in the nanocomposite materials (Fig. 18D).
There is a growing attention in synthesizing bimetallic alloy or core-shell nanocatalysts for enhancing electrochemical activities
based on non-noble metal and metal oxide nanomaterials. Bell et al. [88] demonstrated galvanostatically deposited cobalt oxide film on Au, Pt, Pd, Cu, and Co electrodes for the electrochemical water oxidation. It has been observed that cobalt oxide (Co3O4)/Au thin film was the most active in electrochemical water splitting due to modification of Au-surface which functions as an electron sink in promoting electrophilicity of Co3O4 that helps in the rate determining step. Recently, Yan co-workers [89] developed Au core-Co3O4 shell nanoparticles using simple two-step route. Thus, the Au core was fully covered by Co3O4, making the electron transfer viable only at interface between Co3O4 and carbon support. The electrocatalytic performance of the AuCo nanomaterials almost depends on bimetallic composition, alloying degree, and surface oxidation state. It is a great challenge to synthesize AuCo nanoparticles with controlled size, composition, and surface properties. For instance, Zhong co-workers [90] reported a new way of the preparation of AuCo nanoparticles using a facile one-pot chemical synthesis of AuCo nanoparticles with different compositions and size and
explored the bi-functional synergistic effects in electrocatalysis. Fig. 19 shows the pictorial representation of two-step preparation of Au-Co core-shell nanoparticles. For the clarification, in the one-pot synthesis, Au nanoparticles were not formed until the temperature was raised to above 400 K. When pure oleylamine employed as a reducing agent for the growth of Au core and reduction of Co at ≤353 and 450 K, respectively where oleylamine and oleic acid slowly suppress the Au seeds production before the Co coating, ensuing in the formation of smaller sized AuCo core-shell nanoparticles. In the case of precursor injection synthesis method, the precursors of Co and Au were reduced to Au0 and Co0 nuclei when each precursor was injected into the solution of reducing agent, followed by growth of the AuCo seeds. Fig. 20(A,D&E) display the TEM images of as-prepared nanocluster of AuCo prepared by onepot approach. The atomic ratio of Au:Co was 9:91 in the spherical particles with a narrow size distribution of 10.6 ± 4.2 nm. The core–shell nanostructure was identified by the distinct contrast in the TEM image and it showed two phases including fcc Au and fcc Co which has been confirmed from SAED pattern (Fig. 20C). The HRTEM image of a single core–shell nanoparticle displayed a lattice
fringe of 0.20 nm, matching to a weak lattice distortion of the planes of Au (2 0 0) and Co (1 1 1). As Au concentration in the growth medium increased, Au seeds steadily grow to a larger size without sufficient coating by Co clusters. The production of controlled layer-by-layer stacking of transition metal and oxide nanosheets is possibly attained via nature and composition of intercalating ion, and the reaction conditions for the purpose of restacking. As presented in Fig. 21(top), the electrostatically directed assemblies of nanosheets are mainly enlarged via the dehydration energy of the intercalate ion and the presence of coordinating organic ions [78]. The kinetically controlled inter-stacked structure and stacking number of the proposed metal oxide nanosheets is obtained simply by tuning of DG*. Left of Fig. 21(top) represents the presence of organic ion and the right shows the absence of organic ion. The pore structure and charge storage ability of controlled inter-stacking of MnO2 are enhanced through increasing the tuning of activation energy. The tight stacking structures of MnO2 nanosheets were obtained with larger cations having weaker hydration yield a higher charge density and thus a stronger interaction with anionic MnO2 nanosheets (Fig. 21(bottom)). In general, the exfoliated nanosheets of transition metal oxide possess the negative surface charge in aqueous solution in the presence of organic cations such as tetramethylammonium (TMA+) ions. Metal oxide nanosheets are coordinated with both organic cations and water in the solution. The resulting activation energy for those process may be presented as follows: ΔG*= ΔG(Deh_cat) + ΔG(Dis_NS)+ ΔG(Deh_NS). ΔG* represents the activation energy of the assembly between nanosheets (NS) and the intercalant cation, ΔG(Deh_cat) means the Gibbs free energy for
the dehydration of the intercalant cation, ΔG(Dis_NS) shows the dissociation of nanoscheets from TMA+, and ΔG(Deh_NS) displays the dehydration of NS. Thus, a higher charge density of smaller intercalant cation leans to arrange a thicker and more strongly bound hydration shell, which led to strong stabilization of the precursor state. The chemical methods, including electroless deposition, micro-emulsions, and photochemical synthesis methods can potentially produce diverse morphologies and dimensions of Earthabundant transition metal and metal oxide nanomaterials. In general, precursor selection and their compositions, synthesis environments, reagent properties and concentrations, presence of suitable stabilizers, and precursor choice may be intensively manipulated to control or engineer advanced nanomaterials via precise control of reaction rates and/or nucleation.

sections.heading: 3.1. Sensor
sections.text: Nanostructured Earth-abundant transition metal and metal oxides materials with large surface area, unique physicochemical and electrochemical properties, coupled with flexible functionalities have attracted considerable attention for various electrochemical sensor platforms since 1960s [91]. The analytical performance can be readily tuned by tailoring the structures, particle size, surface area and electron transfer properties of the transition metal and metal oxides nanomaterials [92]. As compared to the noble metal based nanomaterials, the Earth-abundant transition metal and metal oxides particularly exhibits great stability, and favorable kinetics during the sensing process in harsh environment (high temperature, strong acidic/alkaline solutions, Cl− corrosion, etc.). Significant studies have been conducted from both scientific and industrial point of view to detect various analytes in environmental monitoring, industrial process control and personal safety [93].

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Gas and volatile organic compounds (VOC)
sections.text:
Semiconducting metal oxides have been widely employed for the detection of combustible, reducing, and oxidizing gases at high temperatures. The sensing metal oxides can use the following techniques including conductometric, amperometric, and potentiometric methods for sensing applications [94,95]. The performance of metal oxides sensor is largely determined by the surface properties (density of surface states, electronic structures, adsorption/desorption parameters and catalytic activity) and electrophysical properties (electroconductivity, oxygen gas diffusion, band gap and type of conductivity as displayed in Table 1 [96]. And the overall sensing response is a multifarious process which be consisted of three factors: (i) the reactions/adsorption step on surface, (ii) the resultant charge transfer at the sensing layer, and (iii) the charge transport mechanism within the sensing layer and the primary electrodes. As shown in Fig. 22 of conductometric scheme [97], the surface adsorbed O2 molecules can take out electrons from the conduction band Ec, leading to a rising band bending and a decreased conductivity. On the other hand, contact of the surface oxygen species (mainly O−) with reducing gases or a spirited adsorption can decrease the band bending and increase conductivity.
The sensing electrode materials consist of binary, ternary and complex metal oxides system with SnO2, ZnO, Fe2O3, CuO, Mn2O3, Co3O4, NiO, etc. [98]. It has been identified that the size and shape of metal oxides play important roles in determining the sensing performance of theses oxides. Recently, Han et al. identified that the displeased charges connected with oxygen ions at the surface of SnO2 facet could be responsible for the higher reactivity towards reducing gases detection (Fig. 23) [99]. Also, the permutation of metal oxides and other elements, for instance, carbon nanotubes and noble metal nanoparticles are also found to be good for many applications [100–102]. Usually, the mixed component sensors are added effective than the entity components unaided due to the synergistic effect. Therefore, a broad range of doping methods counting impregnation, sol–gel, sputtering, and thermal evaporation have been developed for giving various metal additives into metal oxides structure [103,104]. For example, the NiO/SnO2 sensor exhibited an enhanced sensing response (∼56%) for SO2 gas than the bare SnO2 thin film sensor [105]. Besides, the sensing properties are determined not only by their composition, but also by their structural features such as, profile, dimension, and dimension distribution [106]. Therefore, the controlled preparation of nano- or micro-sized metal oxides has attracted considerable attention. Wang et al. [107] fabricated SnO2 nanowire as the excellent hydrogen gas sensors in the range of 10 to 1000 ppm, owing to the presence of large portion of coordinatively unsaturated atoms on the nanowires surface. It has been demonstrated that the sensor response of SnO2 nanowire is much better than the corresponding nanorod, indicating the morphology effect of metal oxides
(Fig. 24). Modern human and industrial activity produces considerable pollutants of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) such as carbonyls, alcohols, alkanes, esters, aromatics, aldehyde and amides [108,109]. VOCs refer to those organic compounds that tend to evaporate under normal indoor atmospheric conditions (gaseous phase). Many specific sources and processes usually originate from industrial wastewater, petroleum refining, natural gas processing and paints [110]. Nowadays, VOCs have been classified as highly toxic or carcinogenic in nature, which may have both short- and long-term impacts towards human health and natural ecosystem [111]. Metal oxides-based conducometric (resistive) gas sensors are widely employed for detecting harmful VOCs, due to their advantages of strong and rapid response, high sensitivity, compact size and feasible on-line operation [112]. However, it also has drawbacks of poor selectivity. In order to enhance the metal oxide sensors performance, one of the most notable approach is the reduction of sensing particle sizes to nanoscale [109]. As a result of higher specific surface area vis-à-vis active sites at nanoscale dimension, the gas
adsorption and sensitive detection is enhanced substantially. Besides, when the size of sensing materials is further decreased to or lower than double layer thickness of the characteristic “space-charge layer”, surface charge-induced changes will generate remarkable alteration in conductivity and the corresponding sensing signal. As displayed in Fig. 25, Ding et al. [113] prepared a series of ordered mesoporous chromium oxides (Cr2O3) for sensing of formaldehyde (HCHO). It is identified that ordered mesoporous Cr2O3 with 12 nm accessible pores and 5 nm ultrathin framework exhibited ∼4.4 times higher response than the counterpart with smaller pores and thicker framework. Moreover, it has very good HCHO detection selectivity over the interference from CO, benzene, toluene, NH3 and moisture.
It should be noted that zirconia-based potentiometric sensors have been extensively investigated for monitoring nitrogen oxides, ammonia, hydrogen, carbon monoxide and hydrocarbons [114,115]. Usually, the crystal structure of zirconium dioxide is stabilized by the addition of yttrium oxide, the so called yttria-stabilized zirconia (YSZ) [116]. Moreover, zirconia-based oxygen sensors, with or without electrode functionalization have been employed for the electrochemical detection of VOCs. As illustrated in Fig. 26, Sadaoka et al. [117] developed a TiO2 modified Pt/YSZ electrode for successful detection many VOCs, including methyl ethyl ketone (MEK), ethyl alcohol, n-butanol, t-butanol, and toluene.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Aqueous analytes
sections.text:
Early electroanalytical techniques have frequently used the hanging mercury drop and mercury film electrodes for detection of
aqueous analytes, but this technique suffers from the growing distress about the environmental toxicity of mercury and the difficulty in handing, storage and clearance [118]. Recently, nanostructured EATM&MO materials have emerged as the potential sensor elements for detection of heavy metals ions, organic pollutants and biological substances in aqueous solutions [119,120]. As illustrated in Fig. 27, Ma et al. [121] identified the UV light irradiation can substantially increase sensitivity of Ti/TiO2 electrode for fortitude of trace amounts of Cu2+, Pb2+ and Cd2+ ions, which is credited to the toning effect among heavy metal ions and the conduction band position of TiO2. Zhou et al. [122] developed a novel L-cysteine functionalized mesoporous MnFe2O4 hybrid nanospheres for the simultaneous detection of Pb(II), Hg(II), Cu(II) and Cd(II) ions. The excellent adsorption capacity of mesoporous nanocluster and Lewis acid-base interaction of supported L-cysteine are combined to improve the detection performance. Yao et al. [123] investigated the electrochemical stripping properties towards heavy metal ions at two in a different way fashioned Fe3O4 nanocrystals such as (1 0 0) bound cubic and (1 1 1)-bound octahedral crystals. It is observed that octahedral nanocrystals exhibit better electrochemical sensing performance due to the different adsorption energy of heavy metals on the sensing surface (Fig. 28).
For real time application, considerable attention has been paid on screen-printed carbon electrode (SPCE) due to its nature of lowcost and simple to mass construction [124]. As illustrated in Fig. 29, Singh et al. [125] reported the electrochemical sensing of 4- nitrophenol using copper oxide nanoparticles casted SPCE electrode, exhibiting good reproducibility and selectivity even for real sample analysis. And the CuO nanoparticles also presented good catalytic activity for the degradation of 4-nitrophenol. Besides, ionic liquids (ILs) are molten salts, comprising of two asymmetrical ions of conflicting charges [126]. The good conductivity, non-volatility and wide electrochemical window facilitate the ILs in many electrochemical sensors applications. Gao et al. [127] reported a disposable As(II) detection platform by integrating the Fe3O4 microspheres with ILs. The Fe3O4-ILs nanocomposite modified SPCE provided even superior show than usually used precious metals.
Quantification of biological substances is of great importance for medical, biological and biotechnological fields. As shown in Fig. 30, Yang et al. [128] illustrated the fabrication of hierarchical porous Co3O4@graphene (Co3O4@G) microspheres employed as an enzyme-free biosensor for glucose. The prepared Co3O4@G microspheres have huge available active sites via porous structure, whereas the graphene sheets suggest constant electron pathways, leading to a higher performance determination of glucose. Tripathy et al. [129] reported a sensitive electrochemical sensor based on electrospun semi-conducting Mn2O3 nanofibers for DNA hybridization sensing. Sensing of Dengue consensus primer with a limit of detection: 120×10−21 M is obtained both in control and real
serum samples, where the low bandgap nanomaterial and definite oxidation state of manganese found to be highly suitable. As compared to the noble metal nanoparticles, Earth-abundant transition metal oxides were found to be non-toxic, enhanced electron transfer and great adsorption during the electrochemical sensing of heavy metal ions.

sections.heading: 3.2. Energy conversion
sections.text: With ever-increasing concerns of the worldwide fossil fuels consumption, particularly the rapid greenhouse gas emissions and serious environmental consequences, sustainable and renewable energy sources gains significant importance towards the modern society [130]. Recently, electrochemical conversion devices such as solar cell, water splitting (hydrogen production) and fuel cells have been demonstrated as promising technologies for clean energy production [131]. As a key component, nanostructured electrocatalyst based on Earth-abundant elements such as alloys (NiMo, FeCo, CoMo, etc.), phosphides (CoP, Co2P, Ni2P, Fe2P, MoP, WP, FeMnP, etc.), chalcogenides (MoS2, WS2, MoSx, WSe2 CoS2, CoSe2, and NiSe), phosphosulphides (MoPS, CoPS, FePS, etc.), and metalorganic frameworks (MOFs) (Co@N-C, CoP, CoNx, CoWP, etc.) plays a vital role during these electrochemical reactions, enabling a number of high-performance energy applications [132,133]. Therefore, the pursuit of novel electrocatalysts with better electrochemical performances is needed and remains a great challenge in finding low cost Earth abundant materials.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Photoelectrochemical energy conversion
sections.text:
Honda and Fujishima pointed out the purpose of photoelectrochemical cells for solar energy conversion and storage in early 1970 [134]. They developed a n-type semiconducting TiO2 anodes for the water oxidation to O2 with a considerably less positive electrochemical potential, solving the bottlenecks of by means of sunlight produce H2 and O2 from water [135]. This process is now well known as photoelectrolysis (Fig. 31), attracting considerable interest from both the fundamental and practical perspectives. It operates on a similar principle of two redox systems [136,137]: One react with the holes on the semiconductor electrode surface and the other react at the counter-electrode. In this device, solar energy can be converted to hydrogen [138], which is a nonpolluting, renewable, and very flexible fuel and energy carrier. Besides, hydrogen is also a fundamental chemical feedstock employed in the larger scale ammonia synthesis and petroleum refining.
Earth-abundant semiconducting transition metal oxides are attractive photoanodes for water oxidation, due to the relatively high electronegativity of oxygen and the formation of stable O2− anions compounds [139,140]. The main factor for the differences in the oxides valence-band energy is the occupancy of metal d band. Empty d bands (such as Ti4+, V5+, Nb5+ and W6+) of transition metal oxides possess valence band energy levels strongly supported by the O 2p levels, resulting in low and stable valence band energy towards water oxidation under photoelectrochemical (PEC) operation. Titanium dioxide (TiO2) and tungsten trioxide (WO3) have usually been the photoelectrochemical semiconductors due to the advantages of low cost, chemical inertness, UV photo-activity and chemical stability [141,142]. However, owing to its too large band gap (TiO2 Eg= 3.2 eV, and WO3 Eg=2.6 eV, as shown in Fig. 32 [138], it could only harvest the ultraviolet fraction of the solar emission to obtain squat conversion efficiencies. A vast amount of effort has been focused to change the spectral reply of TiO2 into the visible region through doping or adding mid-gap defect states (such as oxygen deficiencies), or to prepare substitute oxides achieving water splitting through visible light [143]. Considerable effort has been concentrated on Fe2O3 [144], given its great abundance and stability in basic electrolytes. Up to 4mA·cm−2 have been achieved for the solar water oxidation photocurrents over Fe2O3, but it is much lower than the theoretical maximum value of
12mA·cm−2 possibly due to its poor semiconducting properties. The limitations of binary oxides force researchers to shift to ternary and complex multinary oxides. However, with about 50 candidate metals in the periodic table, there are nearly 19,000 potential ternary and 220,000 quaternary oxides. Obviously, a strategy is required to identify promising candidates through rational engineering of the bandgaps of these materials [145,146]. In many cases, the bandgap of complex oxides can be approximately predicted by a stoichiometrically weighted addition of the corresponding ones from the parent binary oxides, or sophisticated computational methods by considering crystal-field splitting, electron-electron repulsion and Jahn-Teller effects [147].
Another important photoelectrochemical energy conversion technology is solar cells [148–150]. During the illumination of the semiconductor-electrolyte junction under light, photons have energies larger than that of the semiconductor band gap (Eg) can be captivated and generate electron-hole pair. Accordingly, a photovoltage is produced between an illuminated semiconductor and a metal electrodes, while this photovoltage be the same to the divergence between the Fermi level and the redox potential in the electrode and the electrolyte, respectively [151]. There are already many successful practical application of solar cell using the silicon thin film, compound semiconductor thin film (GaAs, InP, CdS, CdTe, CuInGaSn (CIGS)) [152]. The conversion efficiencies can reach above 25%. However, their high price significantly limits the large-scale applications. Since the pioneer studies of Michael Gratzel from 1991 (Fig. 33), dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) are extensively studied as subsequent invention solar cells due to their rewards
of outstanding act, simple fabrication and cost-effectiveness (10–20% of the silicon-based solar cell) [153,154]. In a DSSC device, the photoanode acts as the dye-sensitized semiconductor based electrode, while the counter electrode be generally the Pt/ITO to facilitate the reduction reaction of electrolyte (I3−/I−). Despite the well-known limitation of TiO2 (band gap and charge carrier transport), the solar cells based on the sensitization of nanocrystalline TiO2 had capable to realize over 22% conversion efficiencies of solar light to electric power, which is comparable to the corresponding thin film solar cell of Si, CuInGaSe2, and CdTe [155]. It has been demonstrated that the morphology, porous structure and crystallinity of TiO2 play important roles in the performance of DSSCs. Consequently, different morphological TiO2 such as nanoparticles, nanotubes, nanowires, and nanofibers, have been employed to fabricate the efficient photoanode films [156,157]. Besides, the integration of TiO2 with other conductive materials has also been explored. It has been reported that the large area graphene nanosheets-TiO2 might substantially advance the conductivity of the bare TiO2 nanoparticle film over 2-times of magnitude, and the power conversion efficiency (PCE) increased over 5- times [158]. Stier et al. [159] extensively studies electron transfer (ET) from isonicotinic acid and alizarin to TiO2 on tens-of-femto seconds time scale, in which the electronic structure and adiabatic dynamics were replicated with ab initio molecular dynamics, and non-adiabatic effects were correlated via quantum-classical mean-field technique. Thus, it is promising to calculate ET rates and differentiate between adiabatic and nonadiabatic offerings towards ET as shown in Fig. 34, which can provide complete perceptive of the elementary processes occurring in DSSC and more information for the catalyst materials design.
