Recently, organometal halides based perovskite solar cells present as an up-and-coming photovoltaic technology [160]. The perovskite structures (ABX3 (X=oxygen, carbon, nitrogen or halogen)), cations are situated in a cubooctahedral site, and B cations are located in an octahedral site [161–163]. When O2− anion is employed, A and B are generally divalent and tetravalent, respectively. Perovskite solar cells originate from dye-sensitized solar cells, in which the adsorption of methylammonium guide halide perovskite on a nanocrystalline TiO2 surface generates photocurrents with an around 3–4% power conversion efficiency since initial exposed in 2009 (Fig. 35). The efficiency had quickly increased over 2-times after a couple of years by optimizing the perovskite covering circumstances, and now it can reach over 20% with promising opportunity for commercialization [164,165]. Earthabundant transition metal oxides such as ZnO, SnO2, WO3, Nb2O5 and Fe2O3, have been explored as the alternative materials for efficient, low-cost, stable and robust photoelectrochemical energy conversion. And many tuning strategies from crystal phases,
doping composite and porous architectures considerations have also been successfully developed to extract the promising potential of these nanomaterials. Furthermore, the emergence of ultrathin 2D materials such as graphene and semiconducting transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) based van der Waals heterostructures offers numerous new opportunities for the construction of solar energy conversion devices [166]. The high carrier mobility, good transparency, and excellent electrical transport behavior create them an surprising materials for transparent electrodes and carrier transporting layers for PV solar cells.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Fuel cell
sections.text:
An extensive diversity of fuel cell technologies are now commercially available, particularly in the fields of portable and remote power sources [167,168]. Fuel cell could be extra classified with the operating temperature since it means the kind of anode fuel, materials selection, customer application and electrical competence (Fig. 36) [169,170]. Polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFC) naturally encompass the lowest working temperature below 100 °C, while SOFCs have the uppermost working temperature usually> 800 °C. High temperature fuel cells (such as molten carbonate and SOFCs) allow internal reforming of hydrocarbon fuels and have entire electrical efficiencies in the range of 45–60%, as compared to the around 35–40% efficiency of low temperature fuel cell [171]. In general, the hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR) held on anode and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) occurs on cathode in H2-O2 fuel cells which may be written as two half-cell reactions as follows [Eqs. (3) and (4)]:
HOR: 2H2→ 4H++4e−, E0= 0 V (RHE) (3)
ORR: O2+4H+→ 2H2O, E0= 1.23 V (RHE) (4)
In a fuel cell, membrane/electrolyte has been used to divide the anode and cathode. Fuels of hydrogen, alcohol or formic acid, are oxidized on anode, while oxygen molecule receives four electrons to water or hydroxy ions in acid or alkaline electrolyte on cathode, respectively (Fig. 37 top) [172]. As a result, the electricity is produced via integrating the anode and cathode reactions. Thermodynamic equilibrium potential for ORR is 1.23 V (RHE) as presented in Eq. (4) and the overpotential is always is connected with fuelcell efficiency. It is desirable that a high performance ORR catalyst may attain the required current density with a low overpotential. Thus, highly active Pt-based catalysts show an elevated current at a great overpotential of ≥300.0 mV. In order to get better ORR catalytic activity, understanding of the kinetics of ORR is required with huge challenging task due to the complex redox processes. The ORR possesses numerous elementary steps which may engage multi-step electron transfer either coupled or decoupled with proton transfer. The investigation of these ORR processes at the atomic level is a vital, to monitor the rate-determining step in ORR kinetics. Fig. 37 (bottom) shows the possible ORR mechanism at the various electrodes [173]. Primarily, oxygen molecule may adsorb on the electrode surface (O2(ad)) and the reduction of O2(ad) can occur by three possible pathways. (1) Dissociation pathway can happen via breaking of OeO bond, forming an O(ad) intermediate, then as-developed O(ad) is reduced to OH(ad) and to H2O(ad). (2) Associative pathway is occurred at which OOH(ad) is initially made from O2(ad) and break the OeO bond, producing the O(ad) and OH(ad) intermediates. (3) Peroxo pathway is predominate when O2(ad) is reduced sequentially to OOH(ad) and to HOOH(ad) prior to the OeO bond cleavage. The ideal electronic structure of the intermediates and its appropriate binding energy could direct to superior ORR catalytic activities. The kinetics of these two reactions are vital for the fuel cells performance, and platinum (Pt) is employed as the most efficient electrocatalyst for both anodic and cathodic reactions for low-temperature fuel cells. However, due to the sluggish kinetics in ORR (5-times slower than that of anodic reactions), more Pt catalysts are required at the cathode (∼10-times higher than
that in anode) [174]. Pt electrocatalyst accounts for nearly 50% cost of a fuel cell, significantly hindering the widespread fuel cells applications. Besides, the stability issues of Pt, such as dissolution, agglomeration, methanol tolerance and cross over are also the some of the challenging problems [175].
To improve the cost-effectiveness and optimize the fuel cell performance, many efforts have been carried out to tailor the dimension and figure of the Pt nanostructures, or design Pt-transition metal nanoalloy electrocatalysts, such as Pt-Fe, Pt-Cr and Pt-Cr-Co [176,177]. Greely et al. [177] employed density functional calculations to obtain the volcano plots and free-energy diagram for the ORR on Pt-based metal alloys (Fig. 38), indicating there is an optimal catalyst design with respect to Sabatier principle. Another strategy is to develop highly efficient alternate electrocatalysts based on Earth-abundant transition metal oxides allowing for their facile synthesis, sensible activity and brilliant strength in oxidative and alkaline environments [178]. The demerits of these nanomaterials are due to their essentially huge band gap, leading to poor electrical conductivity and weak oxygen sorption. Cobalt and manganese oxides are the most attractive metal oxides for the ORR [179,180]. Controlled composition, size, structure and morphology have been attempted to enhance the catalytic activity. Furthermore, the catalytic activities and stabilities of oxides may auxiliary be improved by integrating with advanced conducting substrates like carbon nanofibers, carbon nanotubes and graphene [181]. Other metal oxides of Fe-, Cu-, Ti-, Zr-, Ta-, Nb-, and Sn- have also been evaluated as novel ORR electrocatalysts, while their activities are lower than Co- or Mn-based oxides [182]. Besides, the mixed transition metal oxides (MTMOs) or incorporating with conducting carbon nanomaterials have been also widely employed to improve the conductivity and activity. Recently, perovskite
mixed-metal oxides ABO3 (A is La, Ca, Sr, or Ba, and B is Ni, Co, Fe, Mn, or Cr) exhibit an extremely hopeful Earth-abundant material due to the high electrical conductivity and chemical stability towards ORR [183,184]. The A sites mainly supply to the permanence of on the whole structure, and the suitable interactions of B site with surface adsorbed oxygen species contribute to the enhanced ORR activity. Suntivich et al. [184] (Fig. 39) demonstrated the high ORR activity of perovskite stems from the σ*-orbital (eg) occupation and the coverage of B-site transition metal-oxygen covalency, which acts as a secondary activity descriptor.
Spinel-type oxides (AB2O4) and amorphous metal oxides are also important groups of mixed-metal oxides for ORR electrocatalysis [185,186]. Dai Co-workers [187] (Fig. 40) reported a manganese-cobalt spinel MnCo2O4/graphene composite for the highly efficient ORR in alkaline conditions. It is observed that inorganic-nanocarbon hybrids leads to covalent coupling between spinel oxide nanoparticles and N-doped rGO sheets, as well as the substitution of Co3+ sites by Mn3+. The covalently bonded hybrid presents
comparable Pt/C current density and better solidity as related to standard Pt/C in alkaline solutions. Lee et al. [188] developed a composite made up of Ketjenblack carbon (KB) support amorphous manganese oxide (MnOx) nanowires for ORR. The huge surface active area of the amorphous MnOx nanowires and high density of surface defects provide more energetic and accessible sites for O2 molecule adsorption, thus substantially improving ORR activity. Norskov et al. [189] proposed a method for calculating the stability of the reaction intermediates (* denotes a surface site) and correlated them to the source of overpotential for ORR at the cathode compartment. Fig. 41 (Left) illustrates metals that have either stronger or weaker oxygen bonding than Pt are lower ORR catalysts. At the equilibrium cell potential, Ni strongly binds to O and OH species that the proton-transfer steps become largely activated, and thus ORR becomes very sluggish. On the other hand, the proton transfer on Au surface should be fast enough, but oxygen on the surface is significantly less stable than it is in the gaseous phase, inhibiting the proton and electron transfer. As a result, a volcano trend of different transition metals can be estimated in Fig. 41 (Right) with a utility of the oxygen binding energy. Tian et al. recently developed a ultrathin transition metal nitrides (TMNs) (Ti0.8Co0.2N) nanosheets assembly which showed significant oxygen reduction activities in both acidic H2-air and alkaline Zn-air fuel cells [190]. This catalytic activity is due to the integration of modified electronic effect caused by the doping of cobalt, the high surface area and unique mesoporous structure induced by its nanosheet assemblies, and inherent structural stability of interlaced nitride nanosheets.
Solid-oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) possess elevated efficiencies in a wide variety of fuels [191,192]. Contrasting low temperature fuel cell, CO is a fuel quite than a poisoner and thus hydrocarbon fuels may be employed frankly in SOFCs. Generally employed anode materials for SOFCs are Ni/YSZ (yttria-stabilized zirconia) due to excellent anodic electrocatalytic properties and good current collection [193,194]. However, it usually suffers from the disadvantages of low tolerance to sulfur, carbon deposition, and poor redox cycling stability. Considerable investigations have been performed to substitute zirconia with ceria, and Ni with Cu, in which Cu merely performing as an electron conducting materials with low activity towards carbon formation reaction and ceria instead acts as
anodic oxidation catalyst [195]. Furthermore, different structures of perovskite, fluorite, pyrochlore and tungsten bronze have widely been studied as anodic materials owing to the high electronic conductivity and methane oxidation catalytic activity [196]. Tao et al. [197] reported a La0.75Sr0.25Cr0.5Mn0.5O3 with comparable cell properties to Ni/YSZ cermets for methane oxidation devoid of using surplus steam. The anode shows excellent durability and good process performance in low steam hydrocarbons, overcoming a couple of major bottlenecks of the Ni/YSZ SOFC anodes. Liu et al. [198] (Fig. 42) proposed computational studies at diverse levels to devise sulfur-tolerant SOFC anode materials, as well as ex–situ and in–situ characterizations of varieties and phase formation at anode surface ahead exposure to H2S-containing fuels.
The electrolyte accounts for conducting ions between the electrodes, separation of the reacting streams and internal electronic conduction prevention [199–201]. Under the SOFC operating temperature, the electrolyte must be stable in both reducing and oxidizing atmospheres with lofty ionic conductivity but squat electronic conductivity. The electrolyte can be classified based on its conducting species of oxygen ion and proton (Fig. 43) [201]. Most common fast oxide-ion conducting electrolyte of YSZ has crystal structures of the fluorite kind, AO2, A means a tetravalent cation [200]. Though, its elevated operating temperature (about 800–1000 °C) inhibits its use in small-scale applications. In order to decrease the SOFCs temperatures, another fluorite-type conductor of doped CeO2 is usually employed. Recently, increasing attention has been paid on the ABO3 perovskite electrolyte in intermediate-temperature SOFCs [201]. A successful example is doped lanthanum gallate of LaGaO3, in particular the La1-xSrxGa1yMgyO3-δ(LSGM) series. This material demonstrates clean ionic conductivity in excess of a broad choice of oxygen partial pressure (10−20 < pO2 < 1). The partial substitution of La for Sr and the incorporation of divalent Mg cations into the Ga sub-lattice significantly augment the absorption of the oxygen vacancies within the material structure. Besides, using the transition metal doping, the electrical conductivity of LSGM can be further increased as compared to YSZ and doped CeO2 [202,203].

sections.heading: 3.3. Energy storage
sections.text:
As a measure to counter global warming, the role of energy storage technology in fields such as renewable energy generation and hybrid automobile systems will become increasingly important in modern society. Owing to the untenable environment of nonrenewable energy resources and necessity to manage global warming driven by CO2 emission, the growth in energy storage technology gains much more importance. The electrical energy storage is distant additional significant in current century than it was in the long-ago towards addressing energy crisis, sustainable growth, improving economy/quality of life, and minimize the global warming. Though the energy is ubiquitous in the universe, storage of intermittent non-conventional energy becomes a challenging task. Therefore, storage devices form the key components for electricity supply system to operate more efficiently so that production and consumption are balanced on a continuous basis. In this context, a significant research effort has been made on the development of high energy density storage devices with electrode materials involving nanomaterials [37,204–208]. Electrochemical technologybased batteries and capacitors are considered as transportable or stationary supplies of electric power. In this context, lithium ion batteries (LIBs) as an energy storage device play a dominant role due to high working voltage (∼4 V), high energy density, high specific capacity, light weight, and portability compared to other conventional battery technologies. There are numerous review articles deal with fundamental operating principles of LIBs and various components including anode, cathode, electrolytes, electrode–electrolyte interface, etc. [11,209–212]. This section mainly focuses on comprehensive understanding of the effects of nanosized EATM&MO based materials over lithium battery electrochemistry.
Recent development in design of electrode materials with 0D, 1D, 2D, and 3D nanostructures and their impact on overall electrochemical performance in LIBs are covered. Similar to other electrochemical cell, LIBs consist of three chief apparatus of anode, cathode, and an electrolyte for changing chemical energy into electrical energy as shown in Fig. 44 [213]. Furthermore, the choice of electrode materials has to be made based on their value of electrochemical potential (µA for the anode; and µC for the cathode) and their position comparative to the HOMO–LUMO energy gap (Eg) of the electrolyte (Fig. 44a). In a LIB cell, anode electrochemical potential µA should be inferior in energy than that of the LUMO of the electrolyte in order to prevent electrolyte reduction and decomposition; whereas on the cathode side, µC must be superior in energy than that of HOMO of the electrolyte to avoid the oxidation and other parasitic reaction of the electrolyte. The commercial LIBs introduced in 1990s used graphite anode and layered LiCoO2 (cathode) as an intercalation host for Li+, divided by a porous membrane that permits Li+ in a conventional LIBs. During charge process Li+ deintercalates from the LiCoO2 and passes via electrolyte and intercalates to the layered graphite and the reverse process occurs during discharging (Fig. 44b) and the electrode reactions can be depicted as follows [39,43,213,214].
Cathodic reaction: LiCoO2↔ Li1-xCoO2+ xLi++ xe− (5)
Anodic reaction: 6C+ xLi++xe−↔ LixC6 (6)
The key steps involved during cell operation are: movement of Li+ ions within the electroactive materials, electrode-electrolyte interfacial charge transport, and transport of Li+ ions in the liquid electrolyte. Among these steps, Li+ diffusion within the solid matrix is believed to be rate-determining step in LIBs. In this context, much efforts have been devoted on nanoscale materials to enhance kinetic properties by reducing the diffusion length. Often the electrochemical performance of nanoscale materials exhibit several advantages due to short Li+ path length, high surface area with good electrolyte contact, minimal volume change, new
electrochemical reaction which is not observed over bulk counterparts.

sections.heading: 3.3.1. Nanostructured anode materials
sections.text:
Due to heavy competition in the battery market among different players, the development of Earth-abundant transition metal and metal oxides, including Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, early transition metal oxides including Ti, V, Cr, Zr, Nb, Mo, W, etc. and non-metals such as C, Si, Sn, and Ge were intensively explored to enhance the energy density with simultaneous cost reduction. The thermodynamics and electrochemical kinetics of LIBs indicate that superior specific capacities and rate capabilities at high current can be achieved only when electrode materials offer fast charge transport by providing short diffusion path for charge carriers in addition to better strain accommodation during lithium insertion/extraction and possibility of new Li reaction with nanoscale materials [215]. In this perspective, metal oxides and metal electrodes with 0D, 1D, 2D, and 3D structures strongly believed to be latent substitute for commonly used graphite as the anode material in LIBs owing to approximately 3-fold high specific capacity values of oxides of 3d metal. The key anode performance, including gravimetric and volumetric capacities vis-à-vis energy densities, irreversible capacity loss and capacity fading or columbic efficiency are mainly depends on redox potential vs. Li/Li+, porosity and ionic movement, crystal structure, physical properties such as electronic/ionic conductivities and mechanical stability of individual materials and its chemical composition. On controlling the dimension of materials, Li-ion diffusion length and diffusion coefficient (DLi) could be controlled by the equation t = L2/D wherever L is the diffusion length, D, diffusion constant, and t is time, which reduces with square of the particle size on decreasing from micron to nanoscale particles suggesting a strong correlation between diffusion path length and particle size [216]. Thus, as transition metal oxide nanomaterials offer high conducting properties range from metallic to semiconducting that can be worn in a variety of novel advanced functional materials for LIBs.
To date, graphite with typical intercalation/deintercalation is recognized as a commercial anode material for application in Li ion batteries since 1990s, which has not meet our increasing demands for high-power density and safety requirements [217]. Nanostructured transition metal oxides including Fe3O4, Fe2O3, Co3O4, NiO, and CuO are promising candidates as anode electrodes for next age group energy storage systems in moveable electronics, electric vehicle, and hybrid electric vehicle [43,218–223]. Among them, nanosized transition metal oxides like cobalt oxide, iron oxide, and manganese oxide have paid much attention since 2000s because of their high theoretical capacity [224]. The high theoretical capacity is derived from a new reaction mechanism called “conversion reaction” between lithium and nanosized transition metal oxides as shown below [225,226].
MxOy+2y Li++2 ye−↔ xM0+ y Li2O (M= transition metals) (7)
From the above redox reaction, 2y Li+ per formula unit of metal oxides is stored during charging process through conversion reaction, inducing a structural change followed by amorphization of metal oxides leading to a large volume change and formation of metal clustes (Mo) embedded in Li2O matrix. While discharging, these transition metal clusters are reoxidized to form amorphous transition metal oxides; for instance, 100–200 nm CoO cycled electrode exhibits ∼1–2 nm Co clusters as shown in Fig. 45 [227]. The overall electrochemical reaction of CoO (theoretical capacity 715mAh·g−1) show two phases (CoO+2Li++2e−↔ Co+Li2O) during cycling with voltage plateaus through initial discharge and charge occurring at 0.7 and 2.1 V, respectively. Whereas for Co3O4 (theoretical capacity 890mAh·g−1), Larcher et al. proposed two different lithium reaction pathways governed by structure of the active materials and cycling conditions. For the period of the first discharge, large sized Co3O4 favors lithium insertion to give LixCO3O4, whereas smaller crystals lead to intermediate CoO formation as confirmed by TEM studies according to the following chemical reactions [228].
Co3O4+ x Li++x e−↔ LixCo3O4 (x≤ 2)
Co3O4+ 2Li++2 e−↔ 3CoO+Li2O
Though, most conversion reaction based oxide materials show high theoretical capacity of more than 1000mAh·g−1 than the graphite (372mAh·g−1), they should be further optimized to overcome voltage hysteresis, large volume change, cycle fading, poor rate capability, and Coulombic efficiency. In another strategy, graphene-embedded Co3O4 rose-spheres (G-Co3O4) nanocomposites were prepared through a simple electrostatic self-assembly process (Fig. 46) [229]. The G-Co3O4 exhibited a high lithium storage performance (1110.8 mAh g−1 at the current of 90 mA·g−1 (0.1C)) in comparison to bare Co3O4 rose-spheres, owing to the attribution of good accommodation of the volume change and the enhanced charge carrier transportation for lithium-ion storage.
Special attention has been paid on iron oxide as anode materials due its high theoretical capcity (ca. 1007mAh·g−1 for α-Fe2O3 and 924mAh·g−1 for Fe3O4), low-cost, and less environmental impact. The iron oxide show a well-defined voltage plateau ∼0.8 V indicating a complete reduction of FeOx to a Feo/Li2O by conversion reaction accompanied significant volume change [227]. With intension to overcome the volume alteration and poor cycle life performance, hollow nanostructured hematite has been prepared by templating method exhibiting a reversible capacity of 945mAh·g−1 [230]. Similarly, mesoporous hematite nanostrures prepared using mesoporous silica nanoparticle and MOF [231] were also showed a capacity of 911mAh·g−1 after 50 cycles at 0.2 C rate. The
specific capacity of mesoporous α-Fe2O3 increase slowly during the initial cycle which is ascribed to configuration of a gel-like layer due to electrolyte decomposition. Jiao et al. studied the factors affecting the rate of the α-Fe2O3 using mesoporous, nanoparticles, and bulk α-Fe2O3 and showed that the electron transport to and within the particles was the rate-determining step [232]. The advantage of mesoporous metal oxides includes (i) micron-sized particles has plenty of nanochannels with tap-density equal to that of conventional particles, (ii) maintain good electrical contact within grains, (iii) thin mesoporous wall structures facilitates Li+ diffusion, and (iv) better electrode/electrolyte contact through nanochannels making fast electrode reactions. Thus, mesophase constructed electrode shows optimum balance between high rate performance and high specific capacity [232]. Recently, Fe3O4/FeO/C composite was prepared by reduction of Fe2O3 in presence of C, CO, and H2 which delivered a remarkably high reversible capacity of approximately 1200mAh·g−1 after 100 cycles of repeated charge/discharges at a current density of 200mAh·g−1 [233] indicating that Earth abundant FexOy materials are more promising towards high energy density anode materials.
An alternate potential anode candidate is manganese oxide (MnxOy) due to its low positive redox potential (0.2–0.5 V), large theoretical capacity [MnO2 (1223mAh·g−1), Mn2O3 (1019mAh·g−1), MnO (756mAh·g−1), and insignificant voltage hysteresis (< 0.8 V) but unfortunately show tremendously low electrical conductivity (∼10−7− 10−8 S/cm) hampering its usage as electrode materials [234]. In order to improve the electronic conductivity, Mn3O4 nanoparticles were full-grown on rGO matrix by two-step method. About 10–20 nm high crystalline nanoparticles were highly dispersed on the rGO sheets (∼10wt%) and demonstrated a specific capacity of 1223mAh·g−1 subsequent to 50 cycles at current density of 40mAh·g−1. More importantly, fine dispersion of nanoparticles on the graphene matrix prevents agglomeration of nanoparticles leading to good cycling and favors the movement of charge carriers. Numerous hollow sphere nanomaterials such as NiO [67], WO3 [68], Nb2O3, etc. [235] using soft-template assisted method have been developed by Sasidharan et al. for the LIB anode materials. Recently, much efforts were focused to improve the cycling performance of CuO anodes by developing various CuO nanostructures (thin films, nanowires, hollow spheres, yolk–shell nanostructures, and nanoribbon arrays). In addition to the mono metal oxides, the encapsulation of CuO particles in a conductive matrix to grow CuO/M nanocomposites including CuO/C derived from a Cu-based metal organic framework, CuO/graphene, CuO/ carbon nanotubes, or hybrids with other metal oxides were also anticipated for the use of LIBs. Lyu et al. [236] developed recently Cu/Cu2O hollow microparticles doped with C and N by an one-step reduction and self-assembling method heading for a supramolecular assembly. The as-fabricated composite showed a spirited steady discharge capacity of ≥430mA h g−1 at a current density of ∼500mA g−1 (retention of 90% subsequent to 500 cycles). The achieved hollow structure provided a large void space, accommodated the volume expansion of the CuO particles devoid of changing the secondary particle size throughout insertion of Li. The carbon in the region of the CuO particles armored the potency of the hollow structure and performed a major role in prevent furious of the electrode through the volume vary approach. Thus in conversion mechanism, it is widely accepted that size of particles is a superior consequence on the physical properties due to the bonding arrangements of surface atoms, availability of surface atoms with dangling bonds toward catalyze the Li2O back to M–O and Li+, and the particles division or aggregation include massive collision on the cycling performance of conversion based materials [237].
In recent years, numerous mixed-transition metal oxides (MTMO) nanomaterials with superior electrochemical concert have also been developed as anodes for LIBs, which is a different resourceful approach to alleviate the problems, including vast volume extension and low rate capacity and cycle capability, associated to single-component TMOs. A variety of MTMOs with AB2O4 spinelstructured oxides were fabricated and they demonstrated exceptional lithium storage behaviors; for instance, AMn2O4 (A=Zn and Co), AFe2O4 (A=Zn, Co, Cu, and Mn), and ACo2O4 (A=Zn, Mn and Ni) were investigated and they showed excellent electrochemical performance as anode materials. Xing et al. fabricated inverse spinel-structured Co2+xTi1-xO4, which was a solid solution by means of surplus of quantity of Co [40]. As developed Co2+xTi1-xO4 anode showed the reversible capacity of 766.5mA h g−1 after 60 cycles at 100mA g−1 and even 680mA h g−1 after 400 cycles at 1000mA g−1 as displayed in Fig. 47. This excellent anode performance was interrelated to the atomic level blend of two active materials such as CoO and TiO2 matrix after the first discharge course fashioned through different lithium storage mechanism such as conversion reaction and insertion/extraction, respectively. The CoO offered huge specific capacity via the conversion reaction, whereas TiO2 not only offered fractional capability by an insertion/ extraction mechanism but as well plays as a host framework for CoO in the electrode, suggesting a capable anode material in LIBs use.
In investigate for alternative to graphite anode that merge intrinsic safety feature, low cost, and rate capability, TiO2 and its spinel lithium titanate oxide [Li4Ti5O12, LTO] with Li+ insertion/extraction pathway similar to graphite have been considered due to their outstanding safety characteristics, long-life, and high-power density which follows [238]. Intercalation happens at an electrode potential of ∼1.5 V vs. Li+/Li, as a result the major difficulty of lithium plating is alleviated, exposé the materials considerably safer than graphite [239]. To mitigate the poor electronic- and ionic-conductivities, low specific capacity, and rate capability, most common strategy is to synthesize either nanostructured LTO or modifty the oxide surface with conductive species to achieve high charge carrier mobility. Jo co-workers [240] reported a 1D LTO nanofibers by electrospinning method, exhibiting elevated rate performance of 138mAh·g−1 at 10 C mainly owing to decreased electron and Li+ ion transport distance. Two dimensional nanosheets of LTO with 5–7 nm was also prepared using a hydrothermal method and provided an impressive capacity of 150mAh·g−1 [241]. Subsequently, 3D mesoporous LTO hollow spheres with mesoporous shells were synthesized by Yu co-workers which found to exhibit 115mAh·g−1 at 10 C [242]. Among the 1D, 2D, and 3D LTO materials, the 1D nanostructure exhibits better electron and lithium ion transport by tumbling their diffusion pathway compared other nanostructures. By extending this strategy, Sasidharan et al. [243] reported TiO2 hollow nanospheres of size∼28 ± 1 nm by soft template approach which showed high specific capacity of 181mAh·g−1 at 0.3 C rate following 50 cycles which is superior than that of theoretical capacity of TiO2 [167mAh·g−1] (Fig. 48a). The notable characteristic of the titania hollow nanospheres is the extremely little irreversible capability defeat in the first cycle (∼6.0%) than the micron sized particles (48.0%) and prove that hollow nanospheres not only circumvent the initial irreversible capacity loss but also the void space effectively buffers against local strain and volume change [243]. In another study, N-doped
carbon nanosheets wrapped anatase TiO2 nanocomposites synthesized by hydrothermal method exhibit superior Li storage, durability, and rate performance due to cooperative improvement in electronic and ionic conductivities [244]. The composite electrode demonstrated a specific capacity of 303mA h.g−1 at 0.1 C after 125 cycles and impressive rate capability of 136mAh·g−1 at 5C after 500 cycles with high coloumbic efficiency (99.0%) (Fig. 48b). The superior Li storage is attributed to both Li intercalation in TiO2 and capacitive storage in 2D C3N4 nanosheets.
In a another strategy to improve specific capacity of anode, alloy forming compounds such as M=Sn, Si, Ge, etc. with high theoretical capacity of 999mAh·g−1, 4200 999mAh·g−1 and 1600 and 999mAh·g−1, respectively during alloying reaction to give Li4.4M (alloying product) has been investigated [245]. Though, the anode based on alloy materials endure from huge volume expansion-contraction, which lead to worsening of the electrode and resulting in poor electrical contact affecting significantly the rate capability and cycle life. The tin based nanomaterials undergo irreversible reduction of SnO2 into metallic Sn in the first discharge process during which destruction of SnO2 crystal structure and dispersion of Sn clusters in amorphous Li2O takes place according to the following irreversible chemical reactions. SnO2+4Li++4 e−↔ Sn+2Li2O and Sn+ xe−↔ LixSn (0≤ x≤ 4.4). Similarly, a variety of Si nanostructures including nanowires, nanorods, nanosheets, hollow Si nanostructures, porous silicon and their composites have been extensively investigated for developing high energy density LIBs. Another interesting electrode material is Ge which possess low positive redox potential, better electronic and ionic conductivities, high theoretical capacity but suffers from huge irreversible volume change and associated issues similar to Si based anodes [246]. In this context, Seng et al. demonstrated carbon coated Ge nanostructures and tailored into nanostructured clusters by self-assembly to increase the rate performance. The nanoclusters of Ge and carbon very well retained initial specific capacity at 20 C rate and also delivered impressive capacity of 480mAh·g−1 even at 40 C, suggesting a very high electrode stability and high rate capability of Ge-based alloy electrodes [247].
Thus, the recent literature survey clearly portray that anode electrodes based on EATM & MO nanomaterials are indeed more effectual for rapid Li intercalation–deintercalation reactions facilitated by a short Li+ flow path length and fast electron transportation to the current collector. Although, earlier research efforts were generally relied on using single materials, now-a-days a combination of two- or three- materials as composite or hybrid is being employed to address current problems including specific capacity, volume change or mechanical stability and voltage vanishing in excess of cycling process. Material design therefore is a key to obtain new composite nanomaterials in order to achieve superior electrochemical properties of the anodes. The structure and dimension of the nanomaterials also participate a significant responsibility in the charge transportation kinetics affecting LIB performances [248–250].

sections.heading: 3.3.2. Nanostructured cathode materials
sections.text:
Unlike anode materials, progress of the cathode counterparts has lagged behind and considerable research hard works have been focused on the synthesis and optimization of new positive electrode materials with a large capacity (e.g., ≥200mAh·g−1) and/or high average voltage (e.g., ≥4.0 vs. Li/Li+), the key determinants in improving the energy densities. Enormous research efforts are being taken by the academic and industrial communities focused on the design and optimization of novel cathode electrode materials based on Earth-abundant transition metal oxide nanomaterials. To date, the promising cathode candidates such as nickel-rich layered oxides (LiNi1-xMxO2, M=Co, Mn and Al), lithium-rich layered oxides (Li1+xM1-xO2, M=Mn, Ni, Co, etc.), high-voltage spinel oxides (LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4), and high-voltage polyanionic compounds (phosphates, sulfates, silicates, etc.) are discovered for the LIBs [211,251–253]. Fig. 49 shows the prospects and limitations of these cathode electrode materials [211]. Nanoscale dimensions furnish superior electrochemical performance due to shorter diffusion lengths coupled with better electrode/electrolyte contact area compared to micron-sized particles. For example, Bruce and his collaborators investigated naowires and meosoporous LiCoO2 by using SBA-15 and KIT-6 silica as hard-template and the resultant nanostructured cathode exhibited remarkably less capacity fading as compared to conventional LiCoO2 [254]. Similarly, 2D films of pure LiCoO2 obtained by sol-gel method through cellulose acetate membrane as template delivered about 2.5 times over specific capacity than the conventional LiCoO2 film without any template [255]. Similarly, as macrocystalline layered LiMnO2 suffers structural instability and poor rate performance, and therefore, nanoscale materials were explored to stabilize the layered microstructure by cation doping with elements such as Al or Co. The nanosized LiMnxM1-xO2 (M=Co or Al) with particle size of ∼20–30 nm (primary particle size) showed first discharge capacity of 210mAh·g−1 with charging capacity of up to 245mAh·g−1 in a voltage window of 1.5–4.2 V [256]. Whereas Ni-doped layered Li[Ni0.25Li0.15Mn0.6] O2 nanowires were synthesized by hydrothermal synthesis by simply controlling the pH (∼2–10) and temperature (150–200 °C) to obtain particular morphology. The Li[Ni0.25Li0.15Mn1.6]O2 nanowires showed good rate performances of 95% capacity retention even at 7C rate on account of short diffusion path despite intermixing of Li and Ni metals in the transition metal layers [257]. V2O5, a typical intercalation cathode material with layered structure possessing a strapping interlayer covalent bonding and weak van der
Waals coupling between layers is measured to be a potential candidate due to its intrinsic semiconductivity and capability to transfer multi-electron per transition metal vis-à-vis high specific capacity (294mAh·g−1) [258]. However, similar to other cathode materials, V2O5 also affects from poor cycling durability and rate capacity due to its low Li+ ion diffusion coefficient (∼10−12 cm2 s−1) and electrical conductivity (10−4–10−5 cm2 s−1) and to overcome these problems, nanoscale materials and its composite with carbon nanostructures were extensively explored. In this context, 3D hierarchical V2O5 hollow nano-flowers of size of ∼100 nm were synthesized by solvothermal method for application as cathode materials in LIBs (Fig. 50) [259]. The constructed electrode delivered high discharge capacity of 277mAh·g−1 in the first cycle indicating nearly two Li+ ion intercalation process and 211mAh·g−1 at the end of 100th cycles in the voltage window of 2.0–4.0 V. The hollow nanoflower electrode also presents superior cycling performance with capacity fading rate ∼0.15% per cycle which is attributed to less volume vary through the Li+ ion insertion and de-insertion processes. Another important development in the cathode material is the LiFePO4 with olivine structure synthesized first by Parthi and coworkers, but with limited success in LIBs due to poor electronic and ionic conductivities [260]. In order to address these intrinsic conductivity issue associated with the olivine phase, nanoparticulate LiFePO4 received great attention owing to its less cost, huge thermal and chemical stability compared to other oxide based cathode materials. The intercalation mechanism consists a twophase reaction between FePO4 and LiFePO4 and each phase is exceedingly stoichiometric with low quantity of mixed-valence state and therefore show deprived electronic conductivity. In order to circumvent this issue, 1D nanorods, and 2D nanoplates were investigated by solid state synthesis method which significantly enhances the overall electrochemical properties of LIBs [261,262]. Past one decade or more, enormous efforts were focused on nickel-rich layered oxides [LiNi1-xMxO2, M=Co, Mn, or Al]. In the LiNi1xMxO2 series, the composition with lower Ni content (LiNi1/3Co1/3Mn1/3O2] has already been incorporated in the commercial battery; whereas Ni-rich composition [(1− x) > 0.6] is under optimization to achieve high energy density of about 300Wh/Kg. Furthermore, for Ni-rich high voltage spinel LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4, morphology and surface planes/facets dependent Li+ diffusion over [116,115] or [95] were observed in octahedral, truncated octahedra or polyhedral crystals. Manthiram et al., investigated several high-voltage spinel with differing morphologies and surface facets demonstrating the critical role of surface crystal orientation rather than cation ordering over high-rate capability and cycle life (Fig. 51) [263]. Another cathode candidate, Li-rich manganese based materials Li1+xM1-xO2 (M=Mn and others) has received great attention as high energy density materials due to high voltage, high specific capacity (∼245mAh·g−1) as well as combined cationic redox couples (M/Mn+) as well as unusual anionic oxygen redox reactivity (O2/O2n−) [264,265]. However, the electrochemical properties of these materials are often plagued by a large, gradual decline in working voltage as cycling proceeds (voltage decay) induced by structural instability and local structural disorders. In order to circumvent these issues, extensive studies were carried out by lowering the size of particles from micron to nano dimension with Lirich Mn-based composition and interestingly, nanosized particles showed overall improved specific capacity, rate compatibility,
coloumbic efficiency mainly due to enhanced porosity and surface areas of nanosized particles [211]. Recently, a new concept of core-shell morphology was investigated over Ni-rich materials to satisfy high capacity and thermal durability of cathode materials. Sun et al. studied core-shell particles where Ni-rich Li[Ni0.8Co0.1Mn0.1]O2 forms core domain whereas Mn-rich Li[Ni0.5Mn0.5]O2 serves as a shell part to alleviate the issues like squat specific capacity, and reduced rate capability (Fig. 52) [266]. However, the core-shell structures have different volume expansions between the core and shell domains because of different of extent of volume expansions through cycling. To circumvent this challenge, core-shell concentration gradient (CSG) structures with Li[Ni0.8Co0.1Mn0.1]O2 as core and Li[Ni0.46Co0.23Mn0.31]O2 shell domain was investigated [267,268]. The CSG structure
mitigates low thermal stability, capacity fading, and poor rate capability. In a similar approach, full concentration gradient (FCG)layered cathode material was also synthesized. The FCG- Li[Ni0.75Co0.1Mn0.15]O2 has showed high specific capcity of 215mAh·g−1 at a 0.2 C rate in the voltage range of 2.7–4.5 V [269–271]. In addition, FCG-Li[Ni0.75Co0.1Mn0.15]O2 also demonstrated brilliant capacity retention after 1000 cycles at both 25 °C and 55 °C. In addition, unlike Ni-rich compounds which show a large exothermic peak in the low temperature range of 190–220 °C, the presence of the shell in FCG- Li[Ni0.75Co0.1Mn0.15]O2 delays the main exothermic reaction to a temperature as high as 300 °C signifying the importance of outer shell accountable for noteworthy of thermal properties of LIB cells.
Jun et al. fabricated a core-shell (CS) structured LiNiO2 core and Li[Ni0.87Co0.065Mn0.065]O2 shell using co-precipitation approach [272] in order to provide high capacity and durability of the electrodes. The core-shell structure permitted the extraction of a large capacity from the core material while the shell layer effectively protects the cathode surface from electrochemical degradation and ensures long cycle life. The fabricated CS cathode exhibited the enhanced capacity retention (over 90% of its initial capacity subsequent to 100 cycles) in comparison to the LiNiO2 (Fig. 53). As displayed in Fig. 54, the improved cycling performance was mainly ascribed to the stabilization of the inherently reactive LiNiO2 surface with a Ni-depleted protective shell layer [272]. The developed CS approach offered to harness the high capacity of LiNiO2 and other Ni-rich compositions of nanocomposites with dramatically improved capacity retention, which is a key step toward achievement of high energy density and long lifetime required for EV batteries. The key challenge before LIBs community is to fulfill energy, power, service life, cost, and safety requirements in terms of emerging high-voltage electrode materials. Furthermore to improve the energy density of the active cathode electrodes, two crucial strategies such as extending the voltage window, and the development of novel nanostructured materials based on transition metal oxides with increased operating voltages and/or capacities. The durability/stability of the cathodes and electrolytes as well as their interfaces is central to attain long cycle life and good safety features. In addition, electrode architecture including thickness, density, porosity, and active material concentration/distribution is another important aspect to further enhance the overall energy density and lower the cost of a battery.

sections.heading: 3.3.3. Sustainable recycling of electrode materials
sections.text:
Apart from the selection and design of low cost EATM&MO nanomaterials, the sustainable materials fabrications and recycling processes are also considered for ensuring overall green and cheap of the final electrochemical devices. The application and development of sustainable renewable energy posses a couple of challenges based on time and space perspectives [273,274]. For instance, the traditional lead-acid and nickel-cadmium batteries pose a great threat to the environment owing to the toxic lead, cadmium and so on, while the Li-ion batteries usually consist of less hazardous transition metals [275]. As displayed in Fig. 55, the
four major types of rechargeable batteries distribute like structure and energy storage mechanism relating charge transfer reactions within the electrode materials [276]. Nowadays, the LIBs cathode materials comprise of 37.2% LiCoO2, 29.0% LiNi0.33Mn0.33Co0.33O2, 21.4% LiMn2O4, 7.2% LiNiO2 and 5.2% LiFePO4. Consequently, Li and Co contents of total LIBs are 2–7wt% and 5–15wt%, respectively. According to the United States Geological Survey (USGS), over 40% Li and Co were consumed in the Liion batteries production [277]. However, the limited supply, continuously increasing price and environmentally questionable fabrication methods of lithium and cobalt significantly address the necessarily of efficient metal recovery or recycling.
It has been demonstrated that the recycling of spent batteries can eliminate or decrease the danger of waste release, and satisfy the increasing demand of electrochemical energy-related critical materials. Strikingly, the extraction of 1 ton lithium needs 250 tons of raw mineral or 750 tons of brine, as compared to the 28 tons of spent batteries [278]. Numerous recycling processes such as pretreatment method, pyrometallurgical process, hydrometallurgical process, traditional leaching, etc. are available at present for spent LIBs, including reuse, repair, and recovery [279–281]. Particularly in the pyrometallurgical recycling, metals can be separated between the smelt slags and target alloys at high temperature over 1200 °C. It has advantages of simple and convenient operations for scaling up, high materials purity and less water consumption, while it also suffers from the drawbacks of large amount of volatile organic compounds formation and high energy consumption. On the other hand, the dismantled electrode materials are first dissolved in solvents during hydrometallurgical processes, and then the containing metal ions in the leaching solution can be recovered by precipitation, extraction crystallization or electrodeposition. The hydrometallurgical recovery is benefiting from the complete recovery of metals, less gases emission and low energy consumption (80–100 °C). Nevertheless, a certain amount of wastewater and sludge maybe produced depending on the process design. Chen et al. developed a sustainable and simple method for the regeneration of Li(Ni1/3Co1/3Mn1/3)O2 electrode scraps as new LIBs cathodes [276,282]. Three different extraction processes of direct calcination, solvent dissolution and alkaline dissolution were systematically evaluated. It was found that the spent materials regenerated with solvent dissolution and heat treatment at 800 °C presents best reversible discharge capacities of 150.2 mA·h·g−1 at 0.2 C after 100 cycles with 95.1% capacity maintenance, which is comparable to fresh cathodes. Recently, Zheng et al. prepared a cathode material, LiNi1/3Mn1/3Co1/3O2 (NMC111) from the precursors of Ni1/3Mn1/3CO1/3(OH)2 derived from recycling streams such as Ford EV batteries, GM EV batteries, Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) EV batteries, A123 LFP batteries, and consumer electronics batteries using a hydroxide co-precipitation method in a continuous stirred tank reactor [283]. It is noted that the recovered NMC111 exhibited better rate capability in comparison to commercial NMC111. It is also suggested that the recycled stream composition exhibited a minimal effect on the high-quality precursor, and the cathode material recovered using losed-loop recycling process. This indicates that it may apply to multiple spent Li-ion battery waste streams. Globally many companies like AEA Technology (U.K.), SNAM (France), Toxco (Canada), Umicore (Belgium), etc. have established entire fabrication lines to recycle metals from spent LIBs using pyrometallurgical or hydrometallurgical approaches [284]. However, several research papers reported the recycling technologies of metals from spent LIBs, revealing that some of them reached cost-effectiveness on an industrial scale [285–287]. Meanwhile, research studies have shown that there is no commercial technology to attain the recycling of mixed waste of different
cathodes. The general factors include efficiency, economy, and environment must all be measured and balanced when thoroughly evaluating a particular recycling technology with life-cycle assessment (LCA) [288]. In addition, material and structure design from the Earth-abundant source is simply desirable for attaining high sustainable recycling.

sections.heading: 3.4. Figure-Of-Merit of EATM&MO nanomaterials
sections.text:
The development of highly efficient, stable, and cost-effective electrode materials is of immense significance towards the progress and commercial application of electrochemical sensor, energy conversion and storage technologies. In recent years, numerous advanced nanostructured electrode materials have been developed with excellent activity, selectivity, and stability. In the following section, the comparative analysis of figures-of-merit of EATM&MO nanomaterials in key electrochemical applications to express the vast potential for attaining high atom-utilization efficiency and other unique properties will be discussed.
The electrochemical performance and the cost of electrode materials play crucial roles in the establishment and application of electrochemical technologies. At present, second- and third-row late transition metals, including especially Pt-, Au-, Pd-, Ru-, Ir-, based electrocatalysts are predominant for numerous applications which have been attained through nanostructures of these metals. However, the industrial applications are harshly hindered due to their expensive prices and low abundances in Earth and harmful effects in the biological system. As a substitute, the development of extremely active, durable and biocompatible electrode materials based on EATM&MO nanomaterials has become emerging as a new frontier in electrochemical devices. It has been shown that the EATM&MO nanomaterials are the second most abundant metal in the Earth's crust (4.7 wt%). For sake of cost-effective, sustainability and ecological reasons, with the swift growth of both nanotechnologies and electrochemical technologies, the Earth-abundant transition nanomaterials (so-called sustainable transition metal) have in recent times fascinated growing interest in numerous electrochemical research and development as clearly described in the Introduction Section. Since the year of 2011, the single-atom catalysts (SACs) attract increasing attentions due to the maximized metal-atom utilization efficiency [289,290]. In this configuration, distinctive electronic structure, unsaturated coordination environments of the active centers, high surface area, and active sites can be exposed, while the corresponding intrinsic activity can also be improved via the quantum-size effects. The progress of SACs may facilitate the realistic application of metal resources and ease atomic economy via recycling and maximum atom-utilization
efficiency. The maximum atom-utilization efficiency of SACs enables them to demonstrate an excellent electrochemical performance at a low consumption, benefiting the reduce of catalyst cost. They are usually consisting of different single noble and transition metals atom, anchored on the supports of metals, metal oxides and carbon [291]. For instance, Li et al. [292] reported a single Fe atoms anchored on N-doped porous carbon (Fe-ISAs/CN), in which Fe atoms were 4-fold coordinated by N atoms to generate Fe-N4 porphyrin macrocyclic moieties for excellent four-electron ORR (half potential= 0.9 V in basic media). And there is a also great result of single Co atoms on hollow N-doped porous carbon nanosphere for the acidic ORR ((half potential= 0.77 V) (Fig. 56) [293]. From the DFT calculations, it can be suggested that the electrons can be readily transferred from a single Fe or Co atom to the adsorbed *OH species, significantly facilitating the ORR process. Li co-workers recently developed a highly reactive and stable isolated single-atom Fe/N-doped porous carbon (ISA Fe/CN) materials (Fe loading up to 2.16 wt%) with fine-tunable and uniform pore structure as solid supports to incorporate or anchor metal precursors in order to attain their homogeneous atomic dispersion for enhanced ORR [292]. Tsang co-workers recently prepared single MoS2 molecular layers with high sulfur vacancies on the basal plane via Li intercalation and chemical exfoliation [294]. The resulting S-deficient MoS2 layers preserve easily and bind thiourea-derived Co species with high affinities through refill of the S vacancies to get secluded Co-atoms dispersed on MoS2 monolayers. It has been studied that the unexpected catalytic activity and admirable solidity as well as the short of sulfur loss may be ascribed to muscular covalent attachment of Co-atoms to monolayer MoS2 and the presence of Co-S-Mo interfacial sites. The C vacancies also frequently show in carbon-derived nanomaterials, serving as anchoring sites to bind single metal atom through electron transfer between metal atoms and carbon atoms. Bonde et al. have demonstrated the strong catalytic activity of WS2, cobalt sulfide (CoSx), cobalt-promoted MoS2 (Co–Mo–S), and cobalt-promoted WS2 (Co–W–S) towards the catalytic activity of HER [295]. The intrinsic electrochemical performance of Earth-abundant transition-metal/oxide nanomaterials in catalytic activity, selectivity, durability, energy efficiency and atom economy are majorly actuated by a number of effects, including their shape, dimensionality, support, morphology, novel functionality, atomically dispersed metal site, metal-X (X=N, S, P, etc.) coordination site, oxidation state, composition, confinement, and interparticle distance [296–299]. The extensive range of inexpensive and Earth-abundant transition metal that can be employed to fabricate electrochemical devices provides further environmental and economic advantages.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions and outlook
sections.text:
Earth-abundant transition metal and metal oxide nanomaterials present unique properties and will certainly increase with the momentous efforts aimed transforming to the various marketplace by replacing expensive state-of-the-art catalysts. The present review has highlighted numerous synthetic methodologies for the production of various nanostructures of EATM&MO with different dimensions toward several state-of-the-art electrochemical applications including sensors and biosensors, energy conversion and energy storage systems. The EATM&MO nanomaterials synthetic strategies presented in this review include CVD, hydrothermal methods, electrochemical deposition, and chemical reduction methods with various sizes, morphologies and compositions. Section 3 described various characteristics of the EATM&MO nanomaterials for the electrochemical applications such as sensing platforms, fuel cells, electrochemical and photoelectrochemical water electrolyzer, photovoltaic cells, anodes and cathodes for LIBs. Due to large
abundance, low cost, ease of functionalization and compatibility, the EATM&MO nanomaterials can occupy an unique profile in the advanced electrochemical society, which would serve as an advanced alternative catalyst to precious metal nanomaterials towards electrochemical energy conversion reactions.
Nanostructured EATM&MO materials have been extremely used for the design of several gas sensors towards O2, NO, CO, CO2, etc. based on chemiresistive and potentiometric methods and biosensors such as glucose sensor, lactose sensor, etc. via a mimicking enzyme activity. The design of biosensing platform using of enzyme-free method is a vital for several biomedical applications due to low stability of enzymes. Over the past two decades, numerous studies have been made on the progress of catalysts based on nonnoble transition metal/oxide nanomaterials to replace of state-of-the-art catalysts such as Pt, Ru and Ir-based metal and metal oxides for various electrochemical systems in order to increase affordability and outreach. Due to immediate availability and high theoretical storage capacity, numerous EATM&MO nanomaterials have been employed for the development of electrode materials for battery applications, in particular, LIBs. It is expected that the requirement of EATM&MO nanomaterials with tunable structures and dimensions will rise undoubtedly as electrochemical device market in various fields gets enlarged with time. However, the substantial challenges continue to persist prior to the wide-ranging commercial applications of EATM&MO nanomaterials on account of poor conductivity of oxides, low catalytic activity and difficulty to produce large scale nanomaterials, controlling size distribution and
agglomeration. It is understood that some of the reports based on EATM&MO nanomaterials toward electrochemical applications have taken the relation of expenditure, processability, and scale-up prospect. As an alternate, numerous high electrochemical performance of the EATM&MO nanomaterials were simply shown proof-of-concept and performed in laboratories. In addition, a number of EATM&MO nanomaterials, particularly the ultrathin ones and sub-nanometer scale particles, might require long-term durable properties due to harsh operating condition, limiting in potential real-world applications.
Notwithstanding the aforesaid critical challenges, the following key directions may offer openings in the identification of potential novel EATM&MO nanomaterials as viable alternatives to replace the present electrode materials, including (i) the size and dimension control synthesis of multi-metallic heterostructures to achieve optimal active sites [300–303], (ii) the construction of nanocomposites with carbon nanomaterials such as carbon nanotube, graphene, activated carbon, etc. for improving the conductivity, catalytic activity as well as to accomplish mono dispersivity with low dimensional nanomaterials [304–306], (iii) the establishment of two-dimensional shape of single or few atomic layers of transition metal elements probably via the epitaxial overgrowth of secondary metals [307–310], (iv) the production of nanocomposites with minimal amount of noble metal particles such as Au, Pt, Pd, etc. for attaining high catalytic activity and sensitivity for sensor platforms [311–313], (v) the optimization of multi-metal/oxide nanomaterials to amplify the catalytic activity, charge storage capacity and long-term stability [314–316], (vi) the electronic energy level matching of the catalysts with appropriate reaction by modifying electrochemical electronic structure of the EATM&MO catalyst through chemical functionalization (-COOH, -NH2, -OH, etc.) and doping (N, P, S, etc.) to minimize overpotential and stimulating the reactions thermodynamically [317–319], (vi) the direct growth of hierarchical nanostructures on the electrode surface (binder free) not only reduces the charge transport limitation, but also enhance the accessibility and solidity of the catalytically active sites [320,321], (vii) understand the fundamental correlations between morphological structure, dimension, composition and catalytic activity of transition metal/oxide nanomaterials [322–324], and (viii) the choice of materials and novel design of nanocomposites with other materials like alloy, dopant, core-shell structure for furthering new functionality, high conductivity, chemical durability, and high surface area [325–327]. We can easily design suitable materials for the targeted reactions and attain the atomic-economic green electrochemical process when the aforementioned achievements are attained. It is strongly believed that this review has offered a proper framework to improve the materialization of innovations to tackle the challenges that presently obstruct the inclusion of Earth-abundant transition metal/oxide nanomaterials in numerous electrochemical technological applications. This will prolong to benefit biomedical and food industry, environment, transport industry, and society.

metadata.abstractText: Earth-abundant transition metal and metal oxide (EATM&MO) nanomaterials offer numerous positive attributes such as catalytic activity, selective enzyme-mimicking catalysis, energy harvesting and storage, green chemistry and atom economy guided by size and morphology induced intrinsic properties at the nanoscale. Noble metal nanomaterials have long been played a central role and highly efficient for various electrochemical applications but their high cost and least abundance unfortunately make them less attractive towards industrial applications. In this perspective, the design and development of EATM&MO nanomaterials with unique features are imperative in the fabrication of potential electrochemical devices. This review gives an account of the various emerging synthesis of EATM&MO nanomaterials and their nanocomposites using numerous chemical strategies for the state-of-the-art electrochemical applications. A variety of synthetic strategies for the production of diverse size-, morphology-, and compositioncontrolled EATM&MO nanomaterials has been described for emerging applications such as sensing and biosensing, fuel cells, photovoltaics, water electrolyzer, photo-electrochemical water electrolyzer, and energy storage systems (Lithium Ion Batteries, LIBs). Recent progress, important approaches, structure property relations, and future outlook towards the EATM&MO nanomaterials fabrication for diverse electrochemical devices are highlighted.
